business.start.para: The PRESIDENT took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: I desire to ask the Minister representing the Minister of External Affairs, without notice, the following question: —

quote.para: As to the alleged importation of cooks under contract by the Perth Hospital Board, can the Minister yet inform the Senate if the Contract Immigrants Act provisions have been conspired with?

talk.start.para: The answer to the honorable senator's question is as follows:—

quote.para: The 'Collector of Customs, Fremantle, states that no cooks have vet arrived in Western Australia under engagement to the Perth Hospital authorities, but that an application from the Hospital Board to engage such persons at current rates of wages has been forwarded to the Department for the approval of the Minister.

talk.start.para: I desire to ask the Minister representing the Minister of External Affairs, without notice, the following question: —

quote.para: In regard to the alleged importation of a printer's machinist into Western Australia under contract, a question regarding which was asked on 4th September, can the Minister yet say if the law was fully complied with in this case?

talk.start.para: The answer to the honorable senator's question is as follows: —

quote.para: The Collector of Customs, Fremantle, reports that, after his inquires into the matter, he has come to the conclusion that this man did not arrive in Western Australian under contract to the Morning Herald Newspaper Company.

talk.start.para: -Pursuant to standing order 61, sir, I move-

quote.para: That the Senate, at its rising, adjourn until 930 am. on Tuesday,

speech.para: I do so for the purpose of discussing a matter of urgency, of which I have given you due notice.

talk.start.para: If the honorable senator will state what it is I shall ask four senators to rise in their places.

The matter of urgency which I desire to discuss is "The desirableness of so arranging the business of the Senate as to permit of the general elections being held at as early a date as possible without unduly curtailing the right of the Senate to discuss important Bills involving an alteration of the Constitution.”

continue.para: Four honorable senators having risen in their places,

talk.start.para: The honorable senator can proceed.

Upon my arrival here this morning, sir, I was astonished to find that three Government Bills dealing with an alteration of the Constitution had been placed at the bottom of the notice paper. Section 528 of the Constitution provides that such a Bill must be passed by an absolute majority of each House, and submitted to the electors within not less than two or more than six months after its passage. A compliance with that provision means, as we all know, that the general elections must be held about the first week in December. I believe that there is a general consensus of opinion in the Chamber that at the very latest they should be held not later than the first week in that month. To-day is the 21st September. Unless the Senate is prepared to swallow those three important Bills bolus bolus—without an adequate discussion as to their merits or demerits—the elections cannot take place then, that is, if the Government should not give them precedence over measures which are not of so much urgency. The Bills are of first importance, and it is only right that the Senate, as the States' House, should scrutinize them in the closest possible way. One of them provides for the appropriation of special duties for special purposes. To that extent it will take away a financial right from each State, and therefore the Senate ought to be afforded a full opportunity to discuss its provisions. But if the Government keep those three Bills at the bottom of the notice-paper, what chance will the Senate have to discuss them? My contention is that the business should be so arranged as to afford a fair opportunity for their consideration. I do not want an extraordinary opportunity for the expression of my opinion. Including Senator Pearce's measure, there are now on the notice-paper four Bills involving an alteration of the Constitution.
Does the honorable senator want to take the business out of the hands of the Government?

No. But I want the Government to afford the Senate a decent opportunity to discuss four important Bills. If they are not discussed and passed during this session there will be no possibility of doing anything with them for another period of three years.
Is not that what the honorable senator wants?

No; I want to give the honorable senator an opportunity to bring on his Constitution Alteration Bill. The Government Bills to which I refer are the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (State Debts) Bill, and the Constitution Alteration (Special Duties) Bill.
This action is prompted by a leading article in the Age.
I desire, sir, to call your attention to the fact that I have been accused by an honorable senator of having been prompted in this action by a leading article in the Age.
So it is.

I can tell the Senate —and I expect the honorable senator to take my declaration—that I did not see a copy of the Age or hear of its leading article until I had handed in the notice to the President. I do not feel particularly interested in the first two of those three Bills, but that is no reason why other honorable senators should not desire an opportunity to discuss them. In the third Bill, however, I feel specially interested, because it involves an important alteration of the Constitution affecting not only the interests of each State, but every individual therein. It involves an alteration, which, if made, would give the Government an opportunity of piling indirect taxation upon the shoulders of poor people throughout the Commonwealth. I am utterly opposed to such a system of carrying on the business of the country. Poor people have been fleeced long enough by indirect taxation, and I want to deprive every Government of the opportunity to add to their burden. If the Government do not bring forward the Bill, how can we possibly empress our opinion? Unless they afford such an opportunity, it will never get through the Senate if I can prevent its passage. There is a still more important Bill than any one of the three Senate Bills, and that is the Bill in charge of Senator Pearce to enable the Commonwealth to nationalize industries when they have become monopolies, or inimical to the interests of the public. As a member of the Labour Party, I have been specially interested in the measure. It is taking a power which I contend the Commonwealth ought to hive, and unless it is dealt with this session, the matter will be shelved for a period of three years. We have been passing Bills dealing with trusts, combines, and monopolies; but, from my point of view, all that time has been virtually wasted, and the only effective remedy is that which is provided in the Constitution Alteration (Nationalization of Monopolies) Bill. There will be no chance of referring that measure to the electors for the next three years unless it is passed two months before the ensuing elections.
The honorable senator was not so anxious about it three months ago. He said that he would not stop here at night for any one.

Senator McGregor never heard me oppose the measure in any way. I am most anxious to do the business in which the Labour Party are particularly interested, and I have not skedaddled away from the Senate as often as the honorable senator who makes these insinuations against me. The Minister of Defence knows that I have been willing to sit up night after night to assist the Government in their business.
I know that the honorable senator was prepared to sit up all night to crush me out.
Yes, and I should be prepared to do the same thing again to-morrow.
Surely not while the alliance is on?

I do not know why that should be said. I have made no insinuations against other honorable senators. But the fact is that if we do not swallow all that some honorable senators think we ought to swallow, we are to be attacked, and all sorts of insinuations are to be thrown out in order to discredit our motives.
What is the honorable senator wasting time for now? Is it not self-evident?

I contend that it is a matter of the first importance that the Senate should be given a proper opportunity to discuss proposed alterations in the Constitution before they receive its approval. I ask honorable senators to look at the arrangement of the business paper, and then say whether they can expect to get these important Bills through which must be passed two months before the election takes place. The first Order of the Day is for the resumption of the debate on the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill.
Let us take a vote on that first.

Am I to be compelled to take a vote on a Bill without expressing an opinion upon it? I have not expressed an opinion on the first, second, or third reading of that Bill so far. If I am to be a mere dumb dog, the sooner I get out of the Senate the better.
Is this the way the honorable senator takes the opportunity to express his opinion on that Bill.
I shall take the opportunity when it pleases myself. I am not at the beck and call of any member of the Senate, and no one has the right to decide whether I shall speak now or next week.
Is the honorable senator going to vote for the survey?

I shall tell the honorable senator, and, perhaps, at considerable length, when the proper time comes. I contend that such a Bill should not be given precedence over important Bills involving alterations of the Constitution. We know that the member of the Government who is responsible for this Bill being given precedence of all other measures has made all arrangements to skedaddle away to Western Australia next Wednesday.
He will not have this Bill in his pocket.

When a similar Bill was before the Senate on a former occasion the Treasurer was so sure of getting it that he was over in Adelaide anticipating a wire telling him that it had been passed, in order that he might be the first to convey the glorious news to Western Australia, and reap all the honour and glory. The right honorable gentleman did not get the measure then, and I do not think he will get it this time.
is the honorable senator discussing the question of which he has given notice?
Yes, I think so. I am pointing out that this Bill has been given precedence of more important measures.
That has nothing to do with John Forrest.

I have said all I desire to say on that point, and I bow to your ruling. Other measures given precedence of the Bills proposing amendments of the Constitution are the Spirits Bill, the Excise Tariff Bill, and the Bounties Bill. I am willing and anxious to assist the Government to pass these measures, but if the time of the Senate is to be wasted on measures that have not the support of a majority, no proper opportunity will be given for the discussion of Bills of greater importance.

Why does the honorable senator say the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill has not the support of a majority when he knows that those who are opposed to it have been beaten every time they have called for a division? Of what use is it for the honorable senator to fly a kite like that?
It has not the support of a majority if every member of the Senate were free to speak his own mind about it. Some honorable senators are being constrained to support it.
No insinuations. Who is making them now?

Honorable senators have said so themselves. The Government have expressed a desire that the elections should be held as early as possible, and if possible on the 21st November. If the measures on the business-paper are to be properly considered, it will not be possible to hold the elections on that date. If the Bills proposing amendments of the Constitution are postponed for another week the elections cannot be held until the first week in December. If they are postponed until next week the result will be also that the Senate will be asked to pass them without proper examination. In view of the way in which the Government are managing, the business of the Senate, I could ask whether it is likely that we shalt have even one day on which to discuss these Bills next week. We have not yet discussed the Estimates, and if the session is to close next week we shall be given no opportunity to express an opinion on the management and control of any of the public departments of the Commonwealth. I have a right, in the circumstances, to ask why time should be wasted by giving precedence to measures which are not matters of urgency over measures proposing alterations of the Constitution, which are matters of urgency, unless the elections are to be unduly postponed, or unless the latter measures are to be allowed to go by the board? I appeal to honorable senators on both sides to assist me to influence the Government to make some better arrangement of the business in order that the proposed amendments of the Constitution may be adequately discussed, and it may be possible to hold the elections before the Christmas week. That is all we can expect at the present time, but if the Government are to go on as they are now doing, it is possible that the elections will not take place until the middle of next year.

I think I may call attention to a most unusual discourtesy on the part of the Minister of Defence. We are accused of wasting time, and when the adjournment of the Senate is moved to call attention to a matter of urgent public importance, the leader of the Senate makes no reply. I admit that he is under no obligation to make a statement, but I think that if he did so, it might curtail discussion.
I notified the honorable senator of my motion before the meeting of the Senate, so that he was not taken by surprise.

According to the Standing Orders, honorable senators are confined to a speech of fifteen minutes on this motion, so that they have not much time to waste. Senator Givens has stated that he got a shock when he looked at the business paper this morning. I do not wonder that he did, especially when we remember that the rush of business at the end of a session has often in the States Parliament, and I think also in the Federal Parliament, resulted in the passing of ill-considered measures. It has been whispered to me a number of times that we should get through things quickly, because it is necessary to close the session on next Friday.
We might easily do that if the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill were out of the way. The honorable senator would he prepared to pass all the other measures in twenty four hours.

I think that is a reflection upon honorable senators. We have only to examine the business-paper to see whether the statement is correct. I ask whether it will be believed that Senator Pulsford and other honorable senators opposite will be prepared to agree to the Bounties Bill almost without discussion. I shall myself expect an opportunity to say a few words on such a matter. It will not be expected that I shall sit here like a dumb dog behind the Government when they throw a Bill on the table of the Senate and saying nothing in the interest of the State I represent. I resent insinuations of this character. I do not suppose that I have spoken a dozen times during the session, because I have not thought it necessary to talk on every measure, but it must not be supposed on that account that I am prepared to allow any measure, whatever its character, to go through without a word of protest if I do not believe in it. I have not been used to do that, and I am not likely to alter my usual practice because I happen to be a member of the Senate. It is reported in the press that the Prime Minister has asked that the business of the session should be concluded by the end of next week, because members of the Federal Parliament wish to get back to their electorates. Is it fair, in the circumstances, that the Government should so arrange the business that honorable senators who desire to do that must remain here against the interests of the people they represent, and against their own interests? In one of the Bills relating to the Constitution the Senate might make an amendment, which, of course, would have to go had: to another place ; and in such a case it would be necessary for the Government to keep together an absolute majority of each House. No doubt- the Government think it quite fair under the circumstances to ask parliamentary representatives to sacrifice their private Or public interests. Although we do not know exactly what goes on in another place, we have every reason to believe that there will be measures dealt with, in addition to those already on the business paper; and if that should prove to be so, there is bound to be congestion, with-the re suit that the measures passed will be ill considered, if they are passed at all. In my opinions it is far better to postpone business until the following session, than to have legislation which may prove inimical to the public interests. The representatives of the Government here have repeatedly been asked to lay the Estimates before us at as early a date as possible, and there was, if not a pledge, an implied promise made by the Minister of Defence that he would so arrange as to permit of a few days being devoted to this business. But how can that implied agreement or promise be carried out with the present arrangement of the business-paper? There are nine Orders of the Day, with only one third-reading amongst them, and that third-reading has been declared to be not formal, and may cause a fair amount of discussion. There are two Bills in the committee stage; and the Bounties Bill, which is set down for second reading, is of as much importance, and as likely to cause considerable debate, as any measure yet to be considered. There is wide divergence of opinion regarding the Bill I have just mentioned, and debate may be caused, not because we desire to look at the matter from the point of view of the particular States we represent, but because, from a Commonwealth point of view, we desire to give expression to the principles which we conceive to govern such questions. Altogether there are six Bills at the second reading stage, and, probably, we may be asked to consider further measures. It is only right and fair that proper time should be given for the consideration of any proposals to alter the Constitution. We do not desire to have to deal with half-a-dozen constitutional amendments without giving them the careful consideration they demand and then throw them down before the electors for rejection or otherwise but that, it appears to me, it will be the result unless the Government re-arrange their business.
Does the honorable senator desire the last business introduced to be deat with first?
I desire the business which affects the public interests most vitally to be put in the forefront of the Government programme.
Let us have a vote on the Railway Survey Bill.
I do not agree that, because a particular Bill happens to be at the head of the business-paper, we should be asked to vote on it at once.
Does the honorable senator not desire to get on with the business?
I do, and that is the very reason I am making these remarks. I had thought that when Senator Givens concluded, the leader of the Senate would intimate that he was prepared to re-arrange the business.

I have to thank Senator Givens for his courtesy in informing me that he intended to submit this motion; but I told him at the time, straight to his face, that his proposed action was only another way of wasting time. Whether I am right or not in that view I leave honorable senators to judge. If the motion means anything it means that a certain section of the Senate desire to take the conduct of the business out of the hands of my colleague and myself. If that is done, there is one course open to me, and that is not to any longer endeavour to conduct the business as a Minister—that is plain enough. As to the conduct of the business, what did I tell honorable senators in the early part of the session? I told them, amidst cheers from the opposite side, that I intended to take one question tip at a time, and deal with it to a finish—that I did not believe in chopping about until honorable senators scarcely knew what business was coming on. So far as I have been able, I have carried out that intention, and I shall, to the best of my power, continue to carry it out to the end.

There is business on the notice-paper sufficient for a whole session. I desire to call the attention of representatives of Queensland, and other honorable senators, to the Dill relating to the State debts which has come from another place, containing a provision which, so far as I am aware, has never been hinted at before, and which strikes out of the Constitution one of the safeguards of the Senate. I know I am limited, to a certain extent, in referring to that Bill, but the Senate ought to have a full opportunity to discuss such a subject as that of the transfer of the States' debts. The matter has been discussed elsewhere, and four different schemes have been propounded but, so far, the Senate has, never been officially informed of any scheme, nor have we had an opportunity to discuss the question. The Bill strikes out the safeguard that when a part of the States' debts is taken over, a proportion shall be taken over from each of the States, according to population.
The honorable senator must not anticipate a debate on that Bill, except very generally.

I desire to make my remarks as general as possible, leaving it to honorable senators to fill in the blanks from their know edge of the measure. I do not know what the particular object of this provision is, but if honorable senators desire to give application to my general remarks, I refer them to Coghlan, page 706, where they will find set forth the various loans which mature during the next three years. Those loans are as follows: --

continue.para: Those figures cover the period to the general election of 1909. Honorable senators ought to consider carefully whether the provision of the Constitution to which I have referred is not a wise one, stipulating, as it does that debts shall not be taken over from any one particular State, and at the same time no relief given to all the other States. That was a principle carefully put into the Constitution for the protection of the States. Up to the present no action has been taken under that section. No action has been taken towards the consolidation of the debts; and now we find, at the last moment, that a Bill is sent up to us containing a provision which, I venture to say, no member of the Senate has had an opportunity to consider. We are expected to get rid of that and several other measures in a week. It is simply impossible to do so. We are being asked to amend the Constitution with absolute recklessness. We are expected to shut our eyes, and blindly accept any constitutional alteration which may be proposed.

talk.start.para: The present situation, so far as the Senate is concerned, seems to be one of the most serious that could possibly arise The Senate was appointed to act as the guardian of States rights under the Constitution. That is peculiarly our function. It is the purpose for which the Senate was created. One would have thought that, when several measures closely affecting the relations of the States with the Commonwealth were proposed, sufficient time would be given to the Senate to discuss them in the most careful and exhaustive manner. But, instead of that, we find that an attempt is being made by the Government in plain terms, to thrust its measures down the throat of the Senate without giving us - any adequate opportunity to discuss them. The Prime Minister, speaking in another place a week ago said that he expected and hoped that the session would close on the 28th September. Between to-day and that date there are five sitting days
There is no reason why the time should not be extended for a fortnight.

There is probably no reason, from the honorable senator's point of view, why that period should not be extended, but we know that if that happens a great deal of inconvenience will be caused to a great number of Members of Parliament who have to go before their constituents for re-election.
I have to go before my constituents, the honorable senator has not.

But Senator Pearce's re-election is sure. I suppose, being out of the wood himself, so to speak, he does not care what befalls other honorable senators, whose position with the electors is by not means so definite, and who are called upon to remain in Melbourne much longer than is desirable. I hope that it may be possible to close the session at the end of next week. But to accomplish that object, it is desirable that the most important business should be taken first. What is the most important business upon the notice-paper to-day? The very Constitution under which we are governed contains abundant evidence that an alteration of the Constitution is the most important legislative act which can be performed, either by the Parliament of the Commonwealth or by the people. Let honorable senators consider by what safeguards an alteration of the Constitution is surrounded. A proposed alteration must not only pass both Houses of this Parliament, but it must be passed by a majority of each house; and, after it has run the gauntlet of Parliament, it must be presented to the people of the Commonwealth, and must be passed by a majority of them in a majority of the States. So that by no stretch of imagination can any other business that it is possible to bring before the Senate be said to be of more importance than a proposed alteration of the Constitution. Yet the Government has deliberately put Bills before us, three of which involve alterations of the Constitution, and they, in the last week of the session, are placed at the bottom of the business-paper, whilst a great amount of other important business remains absolutely untouched. The Minister of Defence said this morning that if the Senate took the business out of the hands of the representatives of the Government, there would be nothing for him to do but to resign. Mr. President, if the business of the Country is not to be carried on with more ability and capacity, and regard for the interests of the people than has been the case lately, I shall welcome the resignation not only of the honorable senator, but of the Government of which he is a member.
The honorable senator changes his opinions very frequently.

I change them when the occasion demands change. I am not bound to any set of ideas when circumstances seem to me to involve an altered attitude. The Government, by its action, has deliberately flouted the Senate. Here are measures which are peculiarly the care of the Senate. - Let us look at them for a moment. There is proposed an alteration of the Constitution dealing with the transference of States debts to the Commonwealth. No one will deny that that is a proposal of the very utmost importance. It is a vital question, so far as both States and Commonwealth are concerned. I maintain that no other question that can be brought before the Senate can compare in importance with this, to take from the States the control of their debts. I may be in favour of the proposal of the Government, or I may be opposed to it, but in any case my anxious desire is that the utmost opportunity should be given to me, and to other members of the Senate, being, as we are, the guardians of the rights of the States, for an exhaustive discussion of it. That opportunity has not been given. I do not know whether the Government considers us to be capable of discussing subjects of this importance, or whether it regards the Senate as a quantity of no importance, or desires to thrust its measures down the throat of the Senate, however willing or unwilling we may be to accept them. What the opinion of the Government may be is, however, of very little consequence from my point of view. I am sent here by the people of Queensland to look after their interests. I find that the Government proposes to deal with matters which closely affect the welfare and business of the people of the State. I therefore claim, as my right, that the largest and fullest opportunity shall be given for the consideration of these questions. In addition to the proposal with regard to the States debts another important constitutional alteration is submitted — one which changes absolutely the financial bargain entered into between the States and the Commonwealth when Federation was instituted. It is now proposed to give the Commonwealth power to levy certain Customs duties without incurring the obligation to return any portion of the receipts to the States. Surely that is a question that demands from every member of the Senate the closest, most microscopical examination.
That, of course, is not of such importance as the desert railway!
I am not going to deal with the railway. I have not mentioned it.
Of course, it has not the slightest connexion with this discussion!

It has not in my mind. I am referring to matters which are of very much more importance to the Commonwealth than the mere building of a railway across a sandy desert. If this Government were worthy of its position — if it were worthy of the name of a Government — it would put measures on the notice paper in the order of their importance. If the Government thinks that the survey of a railway across the Australian desert is of more importance from the point of view of the Senate than the three last measures on the business-paper, I, for one, have last all hope of the Government, and consider that the sooner we have gentlemen in charge of the business of the Senate who have a clearer grasp of the importance of one item of business as compared with another, the better it, will be for the people of Australia.

I was very sorry indeed to hear the Minister of Defence say that his practice was when once the discussion on a Bill was commenced, to carry it through; because I find from the Journals of the Senate, that the honorable senator has not always carried through a piece of business when it has been begun. The Minister has not done that in regard to the “desert" railway. If he really wants to save public time, it would be better for him to postpone the order of the Day relating to the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill until more important measures have been dealt with, and then in the order of their importance.
That is the whole object of the motion.

The Constitution Alteration (Senate Elections) Bill, which has been passed, will be quite useless unless the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Bill is also passed. That is an important measure, which ought to be proceeded with. From my point of view, there is another important measure, and that is the Tasmanian Cable Rates Bill. It is only a very tardy measure of justice, which has been promised for a long time. I would urge upon the Minister that by a little re-arrangement of the business on the notice-paper, he could save public time.
The honorable senator wants to take the control of business out of my hands.
No.

I think that Senator Givens deserves every credit for submitting this motion. If the first Order of the Day had not been what it is, there is not a single senator on the other side—although those senators made many imputations while he was speaking—who would not have heartily indorsed his action. I believe that Senator Playford will have good reasons to regret almost every word he uttered.
I am sorry to interrupt the honorable senator, but I think that we ought to have a quorum. [Quorum formed.]

The Minister of Defence gave us to understand most clearly that, having regard to the late period of the session, in his view the importance of the measures which still remain to be dealt with is represented by their order on the notice-paper. If he had had any regard not merely for the Senate, but for the position of the Ministry, be could not have made a more disastrous statement. An analysis of the statement reveals - the fact that the admittedly important measures occupy the lowest - place on the notice-paper. I admire the Minister when he says, "I am in charge of the business, and unless I am allowed to conduct -it as I think fit, you can get somebody else to take my place, "but the remark has not been made at the right time. Directly, and indirectly, the honorable senator has often asked us to let him understand, so far as we can in the circumstances, what is the view of the Senate as to the importance and urgency of certain business. If he will admit that he has done so, the admission will not be in the least degree derogatory to his position as a Minister. What does the motion for adjournment give him an opportunity to ascertain? It enables him to ascertain the strong feeling of the Senate in regard to important work which it wishes to discharge before the session terminates.
Why do not honorable senators discharge the work? Why do they nor vote in a constitutional manner?
That is a most unfair statement for the honorable senator to make.
The honorable senator knows that he is preventing a vote from being taken.

I have not wasted any time, and I recognise that the great object of this motion is to help the Government to economize time. Suppose that the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill had not been the first Order of the Day, is there one who would more cordially indorse what Senator Givens has said than the honorable senator?
No, I would say that we should go on with the Bills before the Senate.

I believe that the honorable senator would join with us in impressing upon the Government the necessity of proceeding with the consideration of important business, and affording ample time to the Senate for that purpose. Has not the honorable senator supported me whenever I have reminded Senator Playford that we want ample time for the consideration of the Appropriation Bill? It is the most important Bill of the session, and it has not yet been received from the other House.
If honorable senators pass the Bill for the survey they can have the Appropriation Bill by next week

Does the honorable senator attach so much importance to that Bill as to allow it to threaten the passage of measures which are of the greatest importance to the Commonwealth, every State, and every citizen?
I hold that the majority of the Senate have the right to express their opinion, and that the honorable senator ought to let them do so.

The majority are exercising their right, but that is not the question under consideration. If the session had still three months to run such a question could not arise, but with only about a fortnight at our disposal, we must begin to consider the relative importance of all the measures.
If this is a minor matter why devote so much time to it?
It is not a minor matter. I would infinitely sooner pass one-half of the Bills with proper consideration, than pass the whole lot rapidly and without consideration.
There is no quorum, sir. [Quorum formed.]

If we pass all these measures, it will be done with the absolute certainty that next session, or subsequently, we shall be asked to amend or repeal them. The statute book is getting filled up with measures to repeal an existing Act, or to repair defects which arose through slovenly consideration, induced very often by want of time. The notice paper does not indicate all the measures which we are to be asked to consider this session. When I asked that the Minister of Defence should arrange for the Senate to have three clear days for discussing the Appropriation Bill, Senator Pearce was the one who immediately interjected, "Three days are not enough." How does the Minister intend to give the Senate three dear days now for that purpose? And how does he hope to face the Senate if that time cannot be afforded? He has admitted his willingness and desire to afford the opportunity for a full discussion.
Let the honorable senators take a division on the third reading of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill, and they can go on with their work at once.
I am not discussing that Bill.
I know what the honorable senator is doing this for.
The Minister in making that sort of interruption when I am seriously discussing the conduct of public business is not likely to further the interests of the Government or of the Senate generally.
The honorable senator keeps on asking me questions, and when I answer him, he "cuts up rough." If he did not ask questions, then I would not answer.

The Minister's one answer to me is. -" Do not discuss this Bill." In addition to the nine Government Orders of the Day on the notice-paper and the Appropriation Bill, I assume that the Senate will be called upon to consider a measure relating to the duty on stripper-harvesters, and also a measure relating to the duties on agricultural machinery. It is hardly necessary for me to draw attention to the importance of the three Constitution Alteration Bills. Does the Minister recognise that the enactment of the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Bill is absolutely necessary in order to give effect to the Constitution Alteration (Senate Ejections) Bill? Does he recognise that the Constitution Alteration (State Debts) Bill is of the vast importance which has been outlined by Senator Drake? Does he recognise that the burning question which has been before the people of Australia for the last five years — the provision of old-age pensions — is certainly wrapped up in the Constitution Alteration (Special Duties) Bill? In those circumstances, is it a source of wonder that Senator Givens, or any one else, should take steps to draw the attention of the Minister to the great risk he is running of those important measures being shelved for this session A most serious situation has been pointed out to the Minister. I hope he will recognise the fact that, but for a certain amount of party difference in regard to one Bill, the Senate almost to a man would insist upon a full opportunity being afforded for the proper discharge of its legislative duties.
Get that measure out of the way, and that will all cease.
What does the interjection imply? It implies that in the deliberate opinion of the Minister that Bill is of more importance than all the others On the notice-paper.
No; it implies that honorable senators have wasted time.
It does not.
I submit that honorable senators have wasted time.

That accusation is almost too ridiculous for me to notice. It simply means that the moment a majority of one, such as it is, is established, the ordinary right of a senator to give to that Bill proper consideration, and in view of the close difference to make every effort to arrive at another conclusion, is to be set aside.
Every fair effort.
Order!

Every effort which has been made to discuss that Bill has been fair, and Senator Playford, as you, sir, have properly recognised, is not in order in imputing improper motives. The Standing Orders are the test of the fairness of the opposition to the Bill. If he can accuse us of having broken them, and thereby obtained an advantage then he would be in a position to say that we had secured an unfair advantage. But the position is, that if any advantage was gained by the breach of the Standing Orders it was gained not by the opponents of the Bill, but by Senator. Playford and those who support him in giving the measure an importance which far transcends that which even its most ardent supporters are entitled to give it.
I must direct attention to the absence of a quorum. [Quorum formed.]

Even at the risk of being charged with wasting a certain amount of time, it is the duty of honorable senators who feel strongly on the subject to protest against the way in which the business is being conducted. At the close of the session a mass of important business is thrown at our heads, and we are asked to deal with it speedily to facilitate the closing of the session. How far has the Government assisted in this matter? They were aware that they contemplated the introduction of a number of most debatable measures, and instead of taking time by the forelock in the early part of the session they allowed the Senate to remain with an insufficient amount of work to do. Many measures might have been introduced in the Senate which have been introduced in another place, and the only reason which can have actuated the Government in adopting the course they have followed is that they consider that the House of Representatives occupies a position of greater importance than the Senate. If the measures to which I refer had been introduced in the Senate they would have been fully debated. That course was not followed, and the result was that we found ourselves without any work to do, and had to take a spell of three or four weeks because measures on which we might have been engaged were submitted to the other Chamber in the first instance. Every member of the Senate, whether he supports the Government or not, should he prepared to set himself against this treatment of the Senate.
Every Government has done the same thing.

With one or two exceptions every important measure that has first been introduced in another place might have been initiated in the Senate. If they had been time of the country would have been saved and reasonable consideration might have been given to the legislation submitted. Senator O’Keefe says that every Government has done the same thing, but he will admit that that is no excuse for the present Government, who took office with a full knowledge of the protests which had been made against the way in which previous Governments had treated the Senate. We should insist that more respect shall be given to the Senate in these matters.
On the merits of the protest we join with the honorable senator, but we know that on this occasion he has no regard whatever for the protest.

I have every regard for it, and Senator Croft must know that perfectly well. He might contend that this discussion has a tendency to delay the consideration of the Kalgoorie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill
Undoubtedly it has.
I have taken advantage of every opportunity to enter my protest against the way in which Government after Government have treated the Senate, and I will continue to do so.
Senator Croft thinks that the honorable senator is doing what is right, but he would sooner do what is wrong in order to save his railway.
That is not fair.
Does Senator Croft know the way in which this Bill has been dealt with?
I do.

On the 8th August the second reading was moved by the Minister of Defence, and on the motion of Senator Pearce the resumption of the debate was made an order for the following day. When the government enable the honorable senator to address himself to the measure? It was brought on again until the 7th September, so that a full month was allowed to elapse from the time the second reading was moved before the first speaker after the Minister was given and opportunity to discuss it. Why did not Senator Pearce insist upon the Government bringing the Bill on earlier? Every member of the senate was aware that there would be strong opposition to the measure. We know that the desire was postpone its consideration until he closing days of the session, in order that honorable senators might be prevented from expressing their opinions upon it fully and freely. We know that honorable senators opposite were waiting to count heads, and when they found that they had a majority of one in favour of the measure they felt it was necessary to risk all in order toa void the change that they had not pushed the matter forwards as they might have done.
The honorable senator is aware that, on a previous occasion, in order to block the measure, Senator Dobson continued to speak until the Governor-General arrived.

I cannot help that. It was Senator Dobson’s duty to his constituents to state his objection to the measure, and he was justified in talking it out when the Government did not submit it for the consideration of the Senate in proper time. Why was not this measure brought forwards at an earlier date? I complain that we should be called upon in the last days of the session to deal with a bounties bill, old-age pensions, preferential trade, the transfer of States debts and provision for the imposition of special duties in order, not merely to carry out a scheme of old-age pensions, but any other scheme the Government might have in hand. Whatever the opinion of honorable senators may be in connexion with these measures, they must all admit that they are of paramount importance, and pregnant with mater for consideration and debate. I ask whether Senator Findley, who, I believe, is a free-trade, is prepared to have a dose of protection thrust down his throat by means of preferential trade proposals of the government?
I should prefer a dozen doses of protection to the infliction to which we have been subjected during the last three or four days.
Then I advsie the honorable senator to take a dose of the physic as soon as he can.
It is good physic.
I do not like it. If the honorable senator is begrinning to think that it is good, I at least have not changed my views on the matter.
The honorable senator shows how much he desires protection when he allows the Western australian Railway to interpose between it.
The Bill is for a survey, and not for the construction of the railway.

The honorable senator knows that as a first step towards a railway we must make a survey of the route. If some honorable senators are prepared to salve their conscience in the matter by saying that they do not believe in the construction of the railway, and that the Bill provides only for a survey, and binds us to nothing, except, perhaps, to threw £20,000 of the people's money away, let them do so. It is charitable to assume that the Government knew three months ago that before the session closed they would submit measures dealing with preferential trade, old-age pensions, and bounties, and they should have introduced those measures long ago, in order that they might be fully discussed. If they think that because they have managed to scramble them through in another place—after sittings of from sixteen to twenty hours, when men are not in a condition to do their work properly—we are going to swallow them without consideration, they reckon very much without their host. They will find that there are members of the Senate who are prepared 'to discuss the merits of all measures submitted to them. They should remember the consideration which we gave to the Tariff, the fights we had, and the compromise which had to be arranged 'to carry the Tariff as it stands at present.
It does not do the Parliament very much credit.

I am sorry to say that it does not, but certain things could not be done, and we had to do what seemed best in the circumstances. With a knowledge of what occurred in connexion with the Tariff, I am surprised that the Government should now propose to increase the duties by means of preferential proposals.
The honorable senator knows that that does not concern him now. What he is concerned about is the blocking of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill.

No; that is Senator Croft's concern, and the honorable senator has been harping upon it ever since I rose to speak. The honorable senator has insinuated that honorable senators opposed to the measure have attempted to "stonewall" it, but I ask him what he participated in on Wednesday morning?
That was the only time I spoke on the Bill.
It is remarkable that the only time on which the honorable senator spoke on the measure should have been when it became necessary to " stone-wall " it.
Because honorable senators opposite would not give a pair for an absent member.

Because we did not know in what way he desired to vote on the motion then before the Senate, which was for the recommittal of the Bill. As a matter of fact, the honorable senator referred to voted for the motion, and if we had agreed to a pair it would have been against his desire.
The caucus of honorable senators opposite is getting pretty strong now. It can influence votes.

continue.para: I ask Senator Croft not to interject.

talk.start.para: If the honorable senator's caucus had exercised its power with the Government, who are supposed to be its willing or unwilling slaves, and to jump as the string pulls them, more time might have been given for the consideration of the measure.
When I have been asked not to interrupt it is not quite fair to attack me.

The honorable senator will have an opportunity to reply to anything I have said. I trust Ministers will so arrange the business as to enable us to deal with the more important measures on the paper 'within the few days left to us before the session closes. It would certainly be fairer for the Government to jettison some of their measures and leave them for the consideration of a new Parliament and of new men, or, at any rate, men who have just been returned with the approbation of the people. Apparently the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill was regarded as of little importance at one time, seeing that it was allowed to sleep for a month or, perhaps, although it was regarded as important, the votes were so doubtful that it was decided to keep it until the last moment, and then thrust it down the throats of honorable senators. There is no reason why the Bounties Bill should not have been introduced months ago. We know that there is only a limited period within which alterations of the constitution can be determined; but, even so, it is very unfair that the Government should in the last moments of a dying Parliament introduce measures so important.

I am sure the Minister will acquit me of anything like factions opposition during the present session; and if I rise now, it is with a sense of the importance of the point which I desire to submit, and which has not been mentioned in the course of the debate. There are measures on the business-paper which cannot pass unless by an absolute majority of this chamber; and if, for example, then senators were absent electioneering, there would be left only twenty-six senators. Under such circumstances, as will readily be seen, a very small minority could absolutely prevent the passage of any of the measures for the amendment of the Constitution.
Thaat is the lookout of the absent senators.

But it is also our “look-out.” This chamber is designed to protect the interests of the States: and those interests are essentially affected by some of the measures to come before us. I particularly refer to the measure-low down on the notice-paper – which proposes an alteration of that section of the Constitution known as the “Braddon Blot.” This section was the subject of the gravest and most prolonged discussion in the Federal Convention. It was contested most keenly by every public man of eminence throughout the Commonwealth; and from time to time it has been the subject of most important deliberations by the Premiers and Treasurers of all the States. Are we, as the last expiring breath of this Parliament is being drawn, to hurry-skurry such as a measure through the Chamber with a bare quorum; and that, perhaps, would be more desirable than the hasty passage of a proposal dealing with a matter which has been the subject of most profoundly deliberation by every leading statesman, and many persons who are not statesman. I think the Government are running a tremendous risk in endeavouring to transact such business when a certain proportion of honorable senators may have left.
In view of the importance of this subject. I call attention to the state of Senate. [Quorum formed.]

What would be the use of having a call of the Senate, even at only one or two days’ notice, when honorable senators were scattered throughout the Commonwealth? There is the greatest chance of these constitutional alteration being defeated owing to the absence of the required absolute majority. If only three or four senators on this side of the Chamber were to vote in the negative on the Government would hoist with their own petard, and rendered absurd in public estimation, because of their conducting parliamentary business as to attain a magnificent futility. This Senate is the custodian of the rights of all states – not the rights of one State, or two States. Nor ought we regard the mendicancy of higher duty to discharge the connexion with the larger questions of expenditure, defence, Tariff alteration, and the great and overwhelmingly important question of preferential trade. These are matters which affect every part and citizen of the Commonwealth, and are of infinitely greater consequence than the forcing through of a railway survey scheme which has hitherto been principally supported by luncheon parties in a back room of this building. Apparently, however, this luncheon party influence, after a good run of four or five years, has come to an end; and we have arrived at a stage when a majority of one – obtained by a process to which I need not again refer, though there was a most unhappy breach of a pair – enabled the second reading to be carried.
And there was the sudden conversion of a Minister
Perhaps that also.
There was no conversion.

The luncheon parties have ceased, and all the points that could be worked in connexion with pairs have been resorted to; and now it is sought to sacrifice every public interest to Western Australian medicancy. The proposed alterations of the Constitution, old-age pensions, Tariff alteration in the interests of McKay and Company, preferential trade nominally in the interests of Great Britain but actually in the interests of Footscray and Collingwood, the defence of Australia, the consideration of all the great subjects involved in the Appropriation Bill—all these are as of no consequence whatever so long as two States of the Commonwealth have a survey conducted within their borders at the public expense. That is the position which the Ministry, unhappily, have taken up. I make no apology for saying that this survey Bill ought to "take a back seat" if the Government mean the greater issues I have mentioned to be brought to a vote. If by any chance, owing to the contingencies I have indicated, those great measures are not dealt with, we shall possibly have the Ministry going to the country with a melancholy wail about their slaughtered innocents and contending that slaughter was rendered necessary by the recalcitrancy of one half of the Senate. Even a minority has a right to use all the forms of the Chamber to cause the delay of what they regard as an undesirable measure, just as the Government have a right to make use of those forms, and, within reasonable and institutional limits, their authority in the Chamber, to further measures to which they attach importance. Why have we so many processes of dealing with a Bill, with all the possibilities of amendment? It is in order that there may be full discussion, and no needlessly hasty legislation, and also that the rights of the minority may be conserved in the performance of what they believe to be their duty to those who send them here. We are not here as the advocates of any railway, the approval of which would enable us to gain votes or kudos at an election; we are here in the interests of the Commonwealth to do that which we believe to be in the public interest. I sincerely and respectfully urge upon the Minister that he should consider the interest of public business rather than that of a railway survey which, on the showing of its supporters, is of no consequence, because nothing is necessarily to be done to carry out the ultimate intention after it is passed. What is the use of wasting time, and jeopardizing the great constitutional problems submitted to us, by pressing through a measure which no one in particular wants, except, perhaps, the author of many pleasant luncheon parties, and two or three gentlemen who would find the passage of the measure—no matter whether an is done under it or not—useful to them in connexion with the coming elections.

I think we should have a quorum present to listen to the debate. [Quorum formed] When this morning I asked the Minister of Defence to make a statement in regard to public business, I never expected to listen to the utterance which fell from his lips. It is one of the most important duties of the leader of the Senate to take an interest in the conduct of its business, and to map out the order in which measures are to be disposed of. My honourable friend has made no attempt whatever to arrange the business in an orderly fashion, He left us just as wise after he had spoken as we were before. He simply told us that he is going to stick to the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill until it is passed, and that then we can do what we like.
Oh no; we can re-arrange the notice-paper.

I gather from several honorable senators who have spoken that my honorable friend's statement that his practice has been to stick to a particular piece of business until it has been disposed of has not been pursued. After the second reading of the Railway Survey Bill was moved, a month elapsed before any other honorable senator said a word upon it. It looks as if the Minister had departed from his proper practice in order to delay this contentious subject till the end of the session, so that he might then be able to force it through. Does not the honorable senator think that the notice-papers of the Senate and of -another place require anxious thought? I should have imagined that the Minister of Defence would have had a conference with the Prime Minister, in order to determine what Bills might be dropped and what business it was necessary to persist in. How can the Bills for amending the Constitution be passed into law in the time at our disposal? According to our Standing Orders, there must be a call of the Senate with regard to them, and of that call fourteen days' notice must be given. I can quite understand that, under pressure of business at the end of the session, Standing Orders may with advantage be suspended, but we ought not to order a call at twenty-four hours' notice. My honorable friend tells us that he is going to ask the Senate to sit on Mondays. Although I am willing to work as hard as any man, and to do my duty as a senator, I say plainly that I am not disposed to consent to Monday sittings. I feel that I am not physically or mentally fit for such an increase of work. As it is, although I breakfast early and am hard at work at my newspapers before half-past eight every morning, I find it impossible to get them read and noted before half past ten. I have no time to consult authorities with, regard to the business to come before the Senate, but have to rush over to this building in order to be in my place as soon as work is commenced. I trust that the Minister will not insist upon that proposal. If be does, the business of the Senate is bound to be done in an unsatisfactory manner. The Bills proposing alterations in the Constitution require to be discussed with the utmost care. I suppose there is no subject of prominent importance in politics to-day which is of greater interest than old-age pensions. When that matter is dealt with, I shall have a few words to say, especially as a notice of motion which I had on the paper dealing with it cannot be reached, because it is amongst the private business which has had to be sacrificed. I shall explain that while I am in favour of old-age pensions, I am not in favour of such systems as prevail in Victoria and New South Wales. In other words, I shall consent to no scheme of old-age pensions unless by it some effort is made to establish thrift, and to enforce a recognition of the principle that every man in the community should endeavour to make provision for his old age. Another amendment of the Constitution deals with the transfer of the debts of the States. That is an exceedingly important subject. But we have not had the slightest opportunity to discuss the various schemes for solving the financial problem which have lately been put before this Parliament. When the Estimates come before us we may reasonably expect to devote four whole days to their consideration. Otherwise they will be passed in a. slip-shod manner, and many criticisms which might fairly be launched against them will have to be withheld through lack of time. The Minister ought to have told us when we are likely to deal with the Appropriation Bill. Does he expect that he will be able to ram it down our throats without our having any opportunity to discuss it?
The honorable senator can get a copy of the Estimates at any time, and can go through them at his leisure.

But what is the use of studying the Estimates if one is not to give the Senate the benefit of his investigations? We also have the Bounties Bill to consider. I have looked into it with some care, and every morning I have brought a quantity of books and papers over to the Senate, thinking that I might secure an opportunity to speak upon it. Does the Minister intend to ask us to proceed with that Bill, and if so, when? I am afraid that honorable senators who have studied the question with care are in danger of forgetting their own arguments in consequence of the delay in bringing the Bill forward. Why does not the Minister tell us what measures are to be dropped? For my own part, I think that the Bounties Bill might as well be laid aside, because Sir William Lyne has admitted that he has never consulted the States about the bounties that would be most useful. The measure is certainly not a fifth part as important as either of the three Bills amending the Constitution. What is the use of pushing on the Railway Survey Bill? The Minister knows that the survey cannot be proceeded with without the consent of South Australia. Why cannot the question be postponed until we see what South Australia is willing to do? South Australia might give her consent in such a way that the Commonwealth would not desire to go on with the work. The Minister of Defence, and even Senator Keating, might find that they could not vote for the construction of the line.

I desire to express the surprise and regret with which I listened to the very petulant remarks of the Minister of Defence. One might have expected that he would have replied to Senator Givens in the way which his indictment demanded. Certainly, he made out a case for a reconsideration of the order in which the business should be planed before the Senate. Whether his arguments were good or bad, the practice, as well as the courtesy of parliamentary life, made it incumbent on the Minister to vouchsafe a proper reply. As Senator Findley expressed a desire recently that there should be a quorum, I think, sir, that his wish ought to be gratified now. [Quorum formed.] The reply of the Minister amounted to a threat that he would feel called upon to resign if the Senate took the business out of his hands. I am not aware that any one has attempted to take that course. All that has been done has been to take the only and the orderly course of bringing before his notice certain reasons why there should be a re-arrangement of the order of the Government business. There was no other way, in which the matter could be raised. If the Standing Orders had provided for a "grievance day," it would not have been necessary for Senator Givens to move the adjournment of the Senate. But that was the only course open to him. It was really childish for the Minister to assert that it was an attempt to take the business out of his hands. The object of the motion was to afford to honorable senators an opportunity to tell the Minister that the order of the business is not such as it ought to be, and is not likely to conduce to a satisfactory conclusion to the session. If he means to say that he is to be above criticism, that no one is to have the slightest right to express an opinion as to the order in which the business should be proceeded with, then he quite mistakes the position of a Minister and the position of the Senate. It is the right of every honorable senator to express his individual opinion on any question, and also as to the order in which various matters should be brought forward. I am greatly surprised that Senator Playford should venture to assert that because he is a Minister he has the right to dictate to the Senate as to what it should and should not discuss. That he of all others should resent criticism of the programme he has submitted surpasses my comprehension.
Does the honorable senator say that the Railway Survey Bill is not in its proper position on the notice paper?

have not referred to that Bill, but if the honorable senator means to inquire whether, in my opinion, it is on the notice-paper in accordance with the Standing Orders, I reply that it is. The notice-paper contains nine Government Orders of the Day. Although it is not permissible for me to refer to the proceedings of the other House, still it is a matter of common knowledge that the Government have expressed their intention to put through this session no less than ten other measures. Assuming that the Government are sincere in their profession, then we shall have to add the ten Bills which have yet to be dealt with in the other House to the nine Bills which are before the Senate. The former are not Bills dealing with minor matters. For instance, there is a measure to introduce penny postage throughout the Commonwealth'. Whether penny postage is in itself desirable or undesirable, the effect which its introduction would have upon the finances of the States renders it imperative that the Senate should have an ample opportunity in which to discuss the Postal' Rates Bill. If in the Senate, which was specially created to safeguard the rights of the States, the discussion of a measure of that kind occupied two days, could it be said by any stretch of imagination that too much time had been given to it? Again, take the Pacific Island Labourers Bill. All the instincts of humanity require that it should be closely scrutinized and examined, for, no matter what views may be held on the question of a White Australia, I venture to say that, even the most ardent believer in the expulsion of the kanakas will not demand that they should be deported except with a due regard to all the requirements of humanity. Therefore, for the credit of Australia, it is necessary that the Pacific Island Labourers Bill should be examined carefully by the Senate before it is passed. In the Preferential Ballot Bill, the Government propose to ask the Senate to deal with a new method of voting, by which the electors would be able to intimate their preference in regard to the candidates at any election. That is proposing not a slight alteration of the electoral system, but a revolutionary change. Could it be said that the Senate, consisting of thirty-six members, was unduly consuming time if it devoted even one day to the consideration of the second reading of a measure of that importance? I desire to refer to the position in which we are likely to be placed in regard to the Estimates. From all sides of the Chamber, quite irrespective of parties or political sympathies, there has been a general expression of regret at the continued slight which has been offered to the Senate by the perfunctory way in which Appropriation Bills and Supply Bills have been practically thrown upon the table, with a curt intimation that unless they were dealt with straight away something would a fair and full opportunity of discussing the financial position of the country. A bad practice has been allowed to spring up, and I venture to say that, later on, a Minister will justify his action on the ground that he is only following an invariable practice. It rests with the Senate to say whether it is content to allow the evil to grow until it gets past cure, or whether it is content to sink into an utterly subordinate position. It is only on a motion of this kind that the Senate can make it abundantly clear that it is not prepared to be thrust into a subordinate position, but will insist upon having a full opportunity in which to safeguard the interests of the Stares be making a close examination of the Estimates. Will any one say that three days would be too much time for the Senate to devote to an examination of the Appropriation Bill? It is a matter of common knowledge that the Estimates for a State frequently occupy the attention of the Legislative Assembly for some weeks, let alone a matter of days. We have to remember that we have not yet received the Tariff proposals with respect to harvesters and agricultural machinery generally. We know that there will be a considerable fight over them. So long as the fiscal question remains unsettled, once it is brought into the arena of party politics, it is as inevitable as that the sun will rise in the morning that there will be a conflict of opinion and a discussion which will occupy a considerable amount of time. I have allowed three days for the discussion of the Estimates, two days for the Postal Rates Bill, a day for the Preferential Ballot Bill, and, considering the time which must be occupied in discussing the proposals with respect to harvesters and agricultural machinery, I should say I have accounted for a full week.

I rise to join in the protest made by honorable senators who have preceded sue against the treatment not merely of the Senate, but of the whole Commonwealth, involved in the manner in which the Government have conducted the business of Parliament during the present session. The session was opened with one of the longest Vice-Regal speeches on record. I have it before me, and I see that it contains thirty-six separate paragraphs, promising the consideration of business of first importance to the Commonwealth. We have some right to assume that the promises made in the opening speech by the Governor-General will be fulfilled by His Excellency's advisers. They include a number of measures, which, so far, do not appear on the notice-paper. We have seen it stated in the press day after day that it is almost certain that the session will terminate within the next few days. In spite of this fact, most important measures are given second and third place to a Bill which, unfortunately, was introduced by the Government, and, still more unfortunately, by previous Governments, and we are spending, our time in discussing a matter of interest to one State only, whilst I say advisedly we are neglecting the interests of the Commonwealth at large in postponing the consideration of legislation we were sent here to pass. His Excellency the Governor-General, at the opening of the session, said—

quote.para: My advisers have prepared a scheme for giving assistance to those connected with the cultivation of the soil, and for the encouragement of new industries.

speech.para: Doubtless that scheme having been prepared so early has been put into the form of a Bill, and will, in time, be brought before the Senate. How are we to find time to deal with such important matters? Apart from the measures referred to, in the Governor-General's speech, we have to consider the business already on the notice-paper. I direct the attention of honorable senators to the motion moved by Senator O'Keefe dealing with the distribution of revenue and expenditure. It is passed over day after day and week after week, when we know that it ought to be settled. There is no question of greater importance to the Commonwealth than that with which it deals. Some little time ago we had every reason to hope that a majority of honorable senators would be prepared as a matter of justice to the weaker States, financially, to accept Senator O'Keefe's motion, with some slight modifications.

talk.start.para: There is no quorum, Mr. President. [Quorum formed.]

speech.continue:
5086
KVD Tasmania
1 0 MULCAHY, Edward Senator MULCAHY
Senator Pulsford moved the following amendment to the motion submitted by Senator O'Keefe:-
`
That all the words after the word "that" in the first resolution be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof— "It is desirable that the present system of dealing with revenue and expenditure, known as the bookkeeping system, should terminate, as permitted by the Constitution, five years after the date when uniform duties were imposed, with, however, due allowance for a limited period to the special circumstances of Western Australia."
To the State I have the honour to represent, that motion and amendment are of the greatest importance, and yet there will be no opportunity afford to give these questions the consideration they merit. One can say with all sincerity that the Senate is not being treated fairly in the matter of the time afforded for the discussion of important questions. We have as much right to scan every item of Commonwealth expenditure as have honorable members in another place; but we know what will happen presently will be that we shall be asked to vote several millions of money in an hour or two.

talk.start.para: Why does not the honorable senator enable us to obtain more time?
Because our time is being wasted in dealing with a measure which there is reason to believe has not the approval of a majority of the Senate.
Why does not the honorable senator allow us to take a division?

Honorable senators are aware that the first time this matter was discussed in the Senate, I stated that I would be no party to obstructive tactics if I were satisfied that a majority of honorable senators was in favour of it.
Honorable senators who were, and are, in favour of the survey are now voting against it.

Honorable senators who last session voted on the question in one way appear to have been converted by some means or other, and are now prepared to vote the other way. There can be no objection to that, because every man is entitled to change his mind if he considers that he has sufficient reason to do so. In spite of the knowledge which Ministers must have that this sill is obnoxious to the majority of the States—
Who said so?
I say so, and Ministers are aware of it.
The honorable senator cannot speak on behalf of every State in the Commonwealth.
I speak only on behalf of my own state; but I suppose I am free to express my opinion?
There is no quorum, Mr. President. [Quorum formed.]

We have nine items on the business-paper, including three Bills proposing amendments of the Constitution, and amongst them there is one which it will be admitted is of paramount importance. We are within a week of the closing of the session, and we have another measure thrust forward, and for what reason? Is the passing of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bid of such great importance to the people of Australia that it cannot be put aside to enable measures of far greater importance to be considered on their merits? Assuming that the Government and their supporters are strong enough to carry this Bill, how can they expect that before the close of next week proper consideration can be given to the other important measures now before the Senate? Are we not sitting from 10.30 a.m. until ii p.m. to facilitate the passage of Government business?
Does the honorable senator think that we shall sit until 11.30 to-night?
I should not be surprised if Ave sat until ii or 12 o’clock to-morrow night; but, in the meantime, I direct attention to the fact that there is no quorum present. [Quorum formed.]
The honorable senator will take his seat. He will have two minutes in which to continue his remarks after lunch.

I am sorry that such an arrangement of Government business has been brought about by this very peculiar state of affairs. I cannot be accused of having occupied any time during the discussion on the Bill, which is the cause of all this trouble?
The honorable senator admits that the Railway Survey Bill is the cause of the trouble?

Undoubtedly; and although we are within a few days, I suppose, of the end of the session, and there are a number of very important questions yet to be dealt with, no progress whatever has been made, either yesterday or to-day. The Government has succeeded in carrying the Kalgoorlie to port Augusta Railway Bill much further than in previous sessions, and I think they ought to be content to pause now, and permit the electors of the Commonwealth generally to express an opinion on the measure at the polls.
That might be suggested in regard to every other measure.

This Bill is on an entirely different plane. It has been shown that only one vote lies between the defeat or acceptance of the Bill, and, further, that there are three honorable senators who voted in its favour, but who, in their own minds, are opposed to it.
How do we know the minds of these honorable senators?

In one way or another, those honorable senators have conveyed the impression that they are not in love with the measure, but, owing to a particular combination of circumstances, they have voted in its favour. Of course, every honorable senator is the master of his own vote, for which he is responsible to his constituents only. On the two former occasions when this measure was before us, we were not on the eve of a general electio0n; and the public interest was, perhaps, not so much aroused as it has been in course of this session when, owing to the long and perhaps acrimonious discussion, their alteration has, to a great extent, become focussed on the measure. Western Australian representatives, who, it must be admitted, have made a gallant fight, have the consolation of knowing that better progress has been made with the Bill than they were able to make previously; but I am certain that if the Government insist on carrying it through its final stages, more valuable time will be wasted by those who seem determined to prevent further progress. I am sure the Government would not carry a Bill which they thought was objectionable to the majority of the electors; and I ask the Minister of Defence and the supporters of the Bill generally, whether it would not be better, in the interests of all parties, to come to an arrangement that no further steps shall be taken with this Bill this session. The short remaining time at our disposal could then be devoted to the measures of enormous importance, which are staring us in the face.
Why not pass the Railway Survey Bill now, and leave the remaining time free for the measures the honorable senator indicates?

There are a number of honorable senators who, rightly or wrongly, seemed determined, by a legitimate use of all the forms of the Senate, to prevent this Bill being passed. We might as well be candid, and admit that that is the actual position
The honorable senator desires that the minority should coerce the majority?
I am very doubtful on which side the minority is.
Let us take a division and see.

However important the Bill may be in the opinion of Western Australian senators, it cannot be denied that there are on the notice-papers measures which, in the opinion of the representatives of the other five States, far transcended in importance.
