Passing over the Tasmanian Cable Rates Bill, which, though important to Tasmania, may be regarded as a comparatively small matter, we come to the Bounties Bill and to the measures for the alteration of the constitution; and even if we cleared the notice-paper of those, there are still other measures of equal importance now before another Chamber. Year after year honorable senators have protested against the presentation of the Appropriation Bill in the last hours of the sessions, and it has been pointed out that there is a promise this year that, at any rate, a few days will be devoted to its consideration. Proper and useful discussion ought not to be curtailed simply because the Government choose to keep back the Appropriation Bill.
Does the honorable senator realize that this “stone-walling” of the Railway Survey Bill is further limiting the time which might be devoted to the Appropriation Bill?

I do; but I think I have the right, under the circumstances, of occupy a few minutes. Unless some arrangement is come to, I am afraid that a great deal more time may be spent in connextion with that Bill.

I wish to remove one or two false impressions which have fastened themselves upon the minds of some honorable senators which regard to my action on this motion. Senator Playford stated that I desired to take the business out of the hands of the Government. I wish to say that my motion was submitted for a specific purpose. Honorable senators have only to refer to its terms to ascertain that purpose. My clear intention was that we should discuss the position of business so that the Senate, as a whole, might give the Government the benefit of its corporate mind. When the Minister of Defence got up, and, in an indignant tone, asked whether I wanted to take the business out of his hands, and said that, if so, some other Government would have to be found, it was so much bounce and bunkum on his part. It has been frequently stated that the Senate cannot make or unmake Ministries. Therefore, the threat of the Minister was absurd. I have never found so much reluctance on the part of this, or any other, Government to go out of office as would seem to be indicated by Senator Playford's remarks. The position which I desired to bring prominently under the notice of the Senate was that we have on our notice-paper at least four Bills involving alterations of the Constitution. In order that they may have any effect whatever, those Bills must be passed two clear months before the date of a general election. It must, therefore, be patent that there is urgency with regard to them. There is no such urgency with regard to any other Bill on the paper. It would not matter whether those measures were passed to-day or on the last day of the session. But it would completely invalidate the Constitution Amendment Bills if they were passed one day later than two clear months before the general election. This day is the 21st September. If those Bills were passed to-day the general election could not be held before the 22nd November. It must, therefore, be a proposition admitting of no contradiction that, unless we are to accept those Bills without discussion, it is not possible to pass them in time for an election to be held at a reasonable date before the end of the year. That is the position to which I object. Those four Bills are of vital importance, from my point of view. One is a Bill which provides that the Government may abrogate the Constitution to the extent of imposing special duties of Customs and Excise, and retain the proceeds for any purpose it thinks fit. I do not intend to allow that Bill to pass without the fullest and freest expression of opinion. Another Bill, introduced by Senator Pearce, the party to which I belong considers to be of the highest consequence. Unless those Bills pass two months before the general election, there is no chance of anything being done with them this year without incurring extraordinary expense. There are other Bills of almost equal importance, with regard to which the same time limit applies. Then there are the Referendum Bill and the Constitution Alteration (States Debts) Bill, the latter of which is a measure of great concern to the States. Inasmuch as the Senate was established to safeguard the interests of the States, it ought not to be expected to pass such a measure at the close of a session without ample discussion. Can we devote to the' measure such consideration if precedence is given to other business about which there is no urgency whatever? It does not matter a straw whether the other Bills are passed today or in the last hours of the session. I have a right to take advantage of the Standing Orders in order to urge upon the Government and the Senate my views as to the state of public business, and I ought not to be subjected to abuse and adverse criticism for doing what I have a perfect right to do, and what I hope I shall always have the courage to do when necessary demands it. Again, we have frequently complained that the Senate has been flouted to some extent by not having an ample opportunity to discuss the Appropriation Bill. What is the position this year? That Bill has yet to come before us. When it comes we shall be asked to do—what? We shall be asked to pass it in the last hours of the session without discussion. We shall be expected to swallow the whole dose without winking an eye. Parliament cannot be prorogued until the Appropriation Bill is passed. The same remark cannot apply to other Bills. Why, then, should precedence be given to them? I trust that the Government will see the force of my argument, and will agree to give precedence to Bills of such urgent public importance as are those I have mentioned. By leave of the Senate, I desire to withdraw the motion. Motion, by leave, withdrawn.

debate.para: Senator PLAYFORD laid upon the table the following papers: -

quote.para: Instructions of the Minister of Defence to Captain W. R. Creswell, C.M.G., Director of the Naval Forces, relative to his visit to England to inquire into the latest naval developments. Report of the Director of the Naval Forces on visit to England, 1906.
Audit Act—Transfers in connexion with accounts of the financial year 1905-6.

debate.para: The Clerk having called on the Orders of the Day,

talk.start.para: What becomes of questions sir?
The time has gone by for asking questions. Two hours after the meeting of the Senate Orders of the Day must be called on.
May I point out the inconvenience?
I have nothing to do with that.
Once when I wished to move the adjournment of the Senate I was not able to do so until formal business had been disposed of.

That may be, but standing order 6o states that after petitions have been presented and notices of questions and motions given, and before the business of the day is proceeded with, a motion may be made for the adjournment of the Senate. That was the motion made by Senator Givens. Under our Standing Orders that motion having been made, and a debate having followed lasting for more than two hours after the meeting of the Senate, we must proceed with Orders of the Day.
We shall miss the Monday sitting unless notices of motion are dealt with.
What standing order imposes the two hours' limit?
Standing order 120 says -

quote.para: If all motions excepting motions for adjournment under Standing Order No. 60 shall not have been disposed of two hours after the time fixed for the meeting of the Senate, the debate thereon shall be interrupted unless the Senate otherwise order, and the Orders of the Day shall be taken in rotation—

talk.start.para: Whose place is it to interrupt the debate?
It has been the practice ever since we have been a Senate, and it is the practice of all Houses of Parliament to fix a period when Orders of the Day shall come on.
Standing order 61 says -

quote.para: Any motion connected with the conduct of the business of the Senate may be moved by a Minister of the Crown at any time without notice.

speech.para: Pursuant to that standing order, I move—

quote.para: That the Standing Orders be suspended to enable questions to be asked, and Government business, notice of motion, to be taken before the Orders of the Day.

talk.start.para: The motion will have to be carried by an absolute majority of the Senate.

As there are 14 ayes and 11 noes, and standing order 433 provides that the Standing Orders shall not be suspended, except on motion after notice, unless there is an absolute majority of the Senate voting for it, the motion is not carried.

debateinfo.title: KALGOORLIE TO PORT AUGUSTA RAILWAY SURVEY BILL

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 20th September (vide page 5014), On motion by Senator CLEMONS—

quote.para: That the President's Ruling—that the third reading of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill can be taken without an adjournment of the debate, or without leave to Senator Turley to resume his speech—be dissented from.

talk.start.para: Before the Senate further discusses this matter, I should like to make some short observations. I have had further time for consideration since the debate was adjourned last night, and I am more than ever convinced that my ruling was correct. Let us look at the position. By an order which is called a sessional order, because it lasts through the session, but which otherwise is no different from any other order, it is provided that the time at the disposal of the Senate for the taking of business shall be divided into two parts, one part in which Government business takes precedence of private business, and another part in which private business takes precedence of public business. But we never have provided either that private business may not be carried on in the time set apart for the Government business, or vice versa. In fact, not only in the present session, but in all previous sessions, it has frequently happened that Government business has been transacted in the time in which private business had precedence, and vice versa. I shall give two illustrations of that from the records of the Senate during the last few weeks. On Thursday, 19th July, Government business was taken at 4.15 p.m.; On Thursday, 9th August, Government business was taken at 5.45 p.m.
After private business had been dealt with.

Of course; and that is just what I am coming to. It is all a question of precedence. We have never set apart a time in which private business should be absolutely taken and public 'business should be absolutely taken. We have only set apart times in which private business should take precedence and Government business should take precedence.
"Unless otherwise ordered."

I am not going to complicate the matter with that question, because that is in a sessional order. After all, it only comes to this - that certain public business has been transacted during the time when private business had precedence. Is that a very great matter? No honorable senator objected. It may be answered – and, I dare say, very truly answered—that honorable senators did not know; but every honorable senator was under a Certain obligation to know what the position was, just as much as I was.
Why have we a President or officials?

The position is that public business has been taken in its wrong precedence—I shall not say with the assent of every honorable senator, but without any objection to the action of the Minister. One of the reasons given—I do not say by the mover of the motion, but by an honorable senator--for the contention that the Order of the Day for the third reading of this Bill has fallen off the notice-paper was that all the proceedings taken on the Bill during the times when private business had precedence were invalid. I Cannot possibly conceive how s-tch an argument can he sustained. We, and we alone, are the judges of our own procedure, and no authority outside the Senate can question whether it is right or wrong. A case which took place in Queensland—the case of Browne .v Cowley—is reported in the Queensland Law Journal of 1895. Mr. Browne, a member of the Legislative Assembly, sued Mr. Cowley, its Speaker, because he had been excluded under an order of suspension made by the House, and his ground was that it was not properly made under the provisions of the standing order. The case came on before Chief Justice Griffith, who is now Chief Justice of the High Court, and he said—

quote.para: I think that in dealing with this point the court ought to bear in mind the rule as laid down by Blackstone, and quoted by Sir James Stephen, in the case Bradlaugh v. Gossett (12 Q.B.D., p. 278) The whole of the law and custom of Parliament has originated from this one maxim—that whatever matter arises concerning either House of Parliament ought to be examined, discussed, and adjudged in that House to which it relates, and not elsewhere."

But I do not think that any court of justice can review the decision of the Chairman. He is called upon to decide on the spur of the moment, so that the business of the House may proceed in an orderly manner. He is human and liable to err. His judgment is liable to be disturbed by the very discussion—probably heated—that is going on. It may be that if he had the opportunity of some days', or even some hours', reflection he would, come to the conclusion that what is done is not really noise or disturbance within the meaning of the standing order; but if his decision on the question of fact thus necessarily arrived at on the spur of the moment were liable to be reviewed, after a long interval, by a legal tribunal, and the protection of the Speaker or officers, or indeed the members of the House, were to depend on the conclusions that that tribunal arrived at, an intolerable burden would be imposed upon members of the Legislature in the discharge of their duties.

talk.start.para: His decision was that the Court bad no jurisdiction.

That is what I am saying—that there is no authority outside Parliament to decide whether the proceedings of Parliament are regular or irregular. That is the whole point. I am referring to this case because it has been argued by some honorable senators that what we have done was illegal. The learned Chief Justice went on to say—

quote.para: I believe this is the first instance in which the ruling of a Speaker, which is subject to appeal to the House itself, has been sought to in submitted to the review of a court of justice. I am not disposed to be the first judge to review a Speaker’s decision on the construction of the standing orders—a function width requires not only the consideration of the printed document, but an acquaintance with the law and practice of Parliament, with reference to which the standing orders themselves are framed.

continue.para: I have quoted these sentences from a decision of the present Chief Justice of the Commonwealth, to show that we need be under no apprehension that any irregularity in our proceedings, so far as the Standing Orders are concerned, will have any effect in invalidating anything we do. The reason given why the President's ruling should be dissented from is that the third reading of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill Cannot be taken without an adjournment of the debate, or without leave given to Senator Turley to resume his speech. It will be recollected that about a month ago I stated to the Senate that where the speech of an honorable senator was interrupted, not by an adjournment, but by a suspension of a sitting in pursuance of any standing order, he could continue his speech without any leave being given. After due consideration, I said I thought that that should be agreed, because it was not fair that any one member of the Senate—leave meaning unanimous leave – should he able to prevent an honorable senator from continuing his speech when it was interrupted, for no reason whatever for which the honorable senator making the speech was responsible, but merely by the arrival of the lunch or dinner hour. That ruling was received with cheers from both sides of the Senate. That seems to me to dispose of the second objection to my ruling in this case. As to the first objection that there was no adjournment, why should there be an adjournment? The sitting commenced at 10.30 a.m. on the day in question. Senator Turley was addressing the Senate, and his remarks were cut short at 1 o'clock by the suspension of the sitting for the luncheon hour. The honorable senator continued his remarks at 2.30 p.m., but it was subsequently found that owing to an irregularity he ought not to have continued them at 2.30 p.m., but at 7.45 p.m. In the circumstances, I say that the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill is properly on the notice-paper, and that when it is called on, Senator Turley, being in possession of the Senate, can, if he pleases, continue his remarks on the Bill. I cannot see how it can be contended that an adjournment is required. No adjournment was required at 2.30 p.m. That is certain. We have seen that in our proceedings to-day. We had a debate initiated by Senator Givens, which was continued up to i p.m., and automatically it went on again when we met at 2 o'clock. If that be so, why should it not be resumed automatically if the sitting were suspended until 7.45 p.m. The only difference in this case is that private business intervened. That does not seem to me to affect the matter. The Senate ordered the Bill to be considered on Thursday. The sitting was continued until late at night. During the siting two suspensions took place, and in the interval between them private business was taken. I cannot see that that alters the aspect of the case at all, and I am quite convinced that the ruling which I gave is correct.

talk.start.para: Senator Clemons having moved the motion now before the Senate, will not be able to speak to it until he speaks in reply, and I therefore take the opportunity to say a few words on the President's ruling. We all recognise, sir, that the case you have cited of Browne v. Cowley shows that where any doubt has arisen in the minds of honorable senators as to the correctness of a ruling, the proper course is for the Senate to discuss and deal with it, and that we can do that without any apprehension of trouble hereafter in connexion with the Law Courts, if any one were so ill-advised as to wish to appeal to them to interfere in any way. It is unmistakably laid down by the judgment cited that the whole matter is open to the discussion and determination of honorable senators themselves.
That is laid down by our own Standing Orders
That is so; but I alluded to the case which you cited because it appears to me that the decision there given confirms the power of the Senate to deal with the matter.
I said that before. It is entirely a matter for our own consideration.

You have pointed out that it has been ruled that where a debate is interrupted by the suspension of a sitting, it is resumed automatically as soon as the Senate re-assembles. We have accepted that ruling, but in this case we are, I think, in a different position, in consequence oi the irregularity committed, inadvertently, no doubt, in contravention of a sessional order. Under the sessional order of the 14th June last, the meeting of the Senate was properly begun at 10.30 am. this morning. The sessional order passed on the 14th June has been complicated by a later resolution of the Senate determining that the Senate should meet at hours which are not prescribed by the original resolution. It has been ruled by you, sir, that the resolution of the 11th September is of no effect, so far as it contravenes the resolution of the 14th June, in respect to the precedence of business, and the question arises whether the resolution of the 11th September is not entirely ultra vires
That would make no difference in this case, because the whole of the proceedings in question were taken under the resolution of the 14th June.
Not the proceedings of yesterday.
Yes; with the exception of what was done immediately after 1.30 p.m.

You will pardon me, sir. The hour fixed for the meeting of the Senate on Thursdays, by the resolution of the r4th Tune, was 2.30 p.m., whilst the Senate met yesterday at 10.30 a.m., by virtue of what? By virtue of an order superseding the original order.

No; the honorable senator has riot looked into the question. There were two orders on the 14th June. One which provides "until otherwise ordered" for the days and hour of meeting, and another which does not say "until otherwise ordered." fixing the precedence of business.
This is the sessional order that was passed—

quote.para: During the present session be Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of each week, at the hour of half-past 2 o'clock in the afternoon of Wednesday and Thursday, and of half-past o o'clock in the forenoon of Fridays, until otherwise ordered.

talk.start.para: "Until otherwise ordered."
The question is whether that applies to Wednesdays and Thursdays as well as to Fridays.
To Fridays only, or the words "until otherwise ordered " would appear at the commencement of the sessional order.

We know that there was a special object in fixing the hour for the meeting of the Senate on Friday morning, and it was in order that the proceedings might be brought to a close on that day at 1. or half-past 4 p.m. The question arises how far the meeting of the Senate yesterday at 10.30 a.m. was legal, although the sessional order contains the words " unless otherwise ordered." The motion of the 11th September was clearly intended to supersede the sessional order fuming the precedence of business. The matter is one on which I think the fullest light should be thrown, in order that we Tay ascertain how far the ruling given is in accordance with the view of the Senate.
The President’s ruling on that point has not been disputed.

But I must consider the matter from that point of view, and I ask honorable senators to do so, as well as to consider it from the stand-point of the President. If we had no right to go on with the work in the morning, we have not yet had the motion for the third reading of the Bill submitted, but are really in the position in which we were left on the Wednesday evening. I concede at once that if Parliament chooses to say that, notwithstanding any irregularity, the work then done was done properly. it is not possible for any honorable senator to appeal to any Court of law for a decision, because we are our own masters, and we have the right to decide. But, however strong our opinion may be, it is eminently desirable that the question should be definitely settled, so as to prevent confusion or disputes in the future.

The honorable senator will see that if we were not legally sitting on the Thursday morning, and the business then done went for naught, then the third reading of the Bill was the first Order of the Day at 7.45 p.m.

If my view be the correct one, the Mister of Defence will have to again submit the motion for the third reading, and honorable senators who spoke to the Bill yesterday morning will have the right to speak again. We have got ourselves into a very awkward tangle, out of which we ought to find a way; and my remarks are not made with an',' desire to cast any reflection on your ruling. I know, sir, that you have given great consideration to the matter, and your views, as is only proper, carry great weight with honorable senators; but, as I say, this is a matter which should be definitely settled, and I ask honourable senators to consider how far they are entitled, as a matter of justice, to disapprove of the ruling which you ha e given. I am not cavilling at your action, nor have I any desire to place myself in a position of antagonism to your ruling, more especially in view of the ability which you always bring to bear in the performance of your duties.

It appears to me that Senator Gould is not very sure of his ground—that he is, at any rate, a little dubious about voting against the ruling of. the President. The position taken up by Senator Gould in regard to the proposed dissent is not the position taken upby Senator Clemons, who submits the motion. Senator Clemons does not object to the ruling which you, sir, gave yesterday in the most positive and emphatic terms, that everything we did in regard to this Bill up to a certain time was perfectly regular and legal, and that decision has not been objected to. Or Standing Orders make no provision for the resumption of a debate which may be stopped by some unusual occurrence, as was the case yesterday. We have no standing order to say whether or not such a debate shalt be resumed in the ordinary way, and I contend that the ruling you gave on that point was the only intelligent and common sense. We met on Thursday morning at half-past io o'clock, and, according to your ruling, that was perfectly right and correct. I moved that the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Fill be read a third time, and the motion was discussed by honorable senators. When the time arrived for the adjournment for lunch at 1 o'clock, Senator Turley was speaking; and when we met again at half-past o'clock the honorable senator resumed, and continued until between 3 and 4’ o’clock. It was then that Senator Neild called attention to an irregularity, and pointed out that Government business was really taking up time that ought to be devoted to private business. The ground on which Senator Neild raised his objection was that the original sessional order in regard to private business had not been properly pealed. I was entirely ignorant of the necessity for seven days' notice, and so forth, which it appears was necessary to enable me to submit a motion changing the time for the consideration of private members' business from the afternoon to the evening That change was made as a matter of convenience, because it enabled me, instead of sandwiching private members' business between two periods of Government business, to take the whole of the latter together. When your attention was called to the matter, you at once ruled that the Government were occupying time which ought to be given to private members' business, and y0u ruled that the latter should be proceeded with. While the discussion on the point of order was proceeding, Senator Turley remained seated, and he did not rise again to resume his speech. The only question which you, sir, had to decide was what had to be the procedure when Ave met after the dinner hour in the evening. There is no standing order providing for such a situation, and in all cases where the Standing Orders fail to meet any particular contingency, the President is asked to give a ruling. The President is put into the position for the purpose of deciding points in which even the Standing Orders cannot help him; and he has to appeal to precedents, and to the practice in other legislative bodies particularly the House of Commons. The President is there for the purpose of advising the Senate as to the common-sense, intelligent way of getting over any difficulty which may arise. Honorable senators look to him for advice and assistance; and there ought to be very strong reasons before honorable senators dissent to any decision given by the President. Unless it can be clearly shown that a decision is not intelligible, or may lead to difficulties. Honorable senators ought to loyally abide by it. In the Parliament of South Australia, even when I had reason to doubt the wisdom of a decision from the Chair, I always acquiesced, and 1 contend that in any deliberative assembly the greatest deference ought to be paid to the determinations of the presiding officer. No decision ought to be called in question unless it can be shown that it is unfair, or will work evil. Or militate against the good conduct of business hereafter; and I defy any honorable senator to say that the decision now under consideration is not eminently fair, or that it will not conduce to the proper order of business, while not damning any honorable senator in any respect. If an interruption of the kind occurs in a debate, the honourable senator who is sneaking at the time is asked to resume when we re-assemble. What else could be done? What absurdity it is to talk about there being any necessity to give fresh notice of motion, or to strike the measure off the notice-paper, and so forth. Evet, if I were the bitterest op ponent of this Bill, I should never conceive it to be my duty to object to a decision given by the President, except for really good and solid reasons. The question referred to by Senator 'Gould has already been decided by you, Mr. President
Not yet.
The President gave his ruling last night, and it was not objected to.
The honorable senator is quite wrong.
I believe I am correct; but whether that ruling was objected or not, the motion now under dicussion raises no objection to it.
That may be.

The ruling given last night, although it may be incidentally referred to on the present occasion, is not one that would be interfered with, even if the motion now under discussion were carried. Under the circumstances, I trust that the Senate will support your ruling, sir, which, in my opinion, is consonant with common sense.

I rise more to ask- a question than to sneak upon the ruling given by you, sir. My point is not as to the desirableness of the proceedings adopted by you in Connexion with Senator Turlev 's continuation of the debate on the Railway Survey Bill, but rather as to the validity of the sessional order of 11th September. I think that you have not given a definite ruling on a point submitted by me yesterday. My, memory is fortified by reading the Hansard proofs of what took place. You intimated that you intended to give a ruling on the point at a quarter to 8 o'clock last night, but you omitted to do so.
what is the question?

It relates to the validity of the sessional order of 11th September as a whole. You said in the course of the discussion that it was not necessary to give a ruling on the whole question at that time, but that you would do so at a quarter to 8 o'clock. But at a quarter to 8 o'clock the Clerk called on the Railway Survey Bill, and the ruling was not given. I took no exception to what was done, but I desire to intimate that when a favourable opportunity occurs I shall raise the point again. The point upon which I desire to obtain a ruling is as to the whole of the sessional order made on the 11th September. I can assure you that I can bring forward strong reasons, supported by precedents faken from our Journals of the present session, for contending that the order of the 11th September is wholly invalid; not merely invalid in part. I do not propose to vote for the motion dissenting from your ruling on the point under consideration. I shall vote to uphold the President's ruling—a course which is consonant with my feelings and my desire to maintain the highest possible respect for our President and for the Presidential chair. But I reserve to myself the right, on some future occasion, to raise a point of order on the matter which I have mentioned.
I quite understand.

I cannot raise the point now, but I may be able to do so next week, at an hour fixed under the order of the 11th September, but not fixed by the order of 14th June. I reserve my right in that matter; but I propose, with a great deal of pleasure, to vote in support of the ruling that you gave last night.

I regret that, not for the first time to-day, I Have to take exception to a remark made by the Minister of Defence. He has made an appeal to the Senate to determine this matter from the point of view of its loyalty to the-Chair, rather than according to its judgment. I take it that that is rather a reflection upon those who may see some reason to cast a vote adverse to the ruling which you, sir, have given. But I venture to say that even those who differ from you fully recognise the obligation which the Minister has referred to of observing loyalty towards the Chair. I do not think that. in your six years' experience as President of the Senate, you will say, speaking with regard to the whole of that time, that there has been any want of loyalty or respect to yourself. Therefore, when the Minister makes that appeal, it would almost suggest either that there was lacking some force in his own contention of which he was aware, or that he assumed that the motion of dissent was submitted from a want of loyalty. I entirely repudiate that suggestion, and intend to give a reason which, I think, suggests that there may be, compatible with common sense, another interpretation than that which you have placed upon the matter submitted to you for decision. The point is this: An irregularity was undoubtedly committed. That is acknowledged by every one. There seems to me to have been two ways by which we could recover ourselves, and get back to the regular track. One was, at the time when the irregularity was detected, to condone everything up to that point, and to assume that—the Senate having taken that course—everything had become regular. The other way by which we could have corrected the irregularity was by reverting to the point at which it commenced. I see no possibility of departing from an irregular track into a regular track, except at one of those two stages—either the, stage at which the irregularity was first committed, or that at which it was detected. It seems to me that you have determined that the irregularity shall be corrected at a point between those two. The irregularity was not detected at 1 o'clock yesterday. It was detected at half-past 3. I contend that if the Senate condoned everything that had happened up to 1 o'clock, it equally condoned everything up to 3 o’clock, at which time the irregularity was detected. If we are going to stand on the fact that the Senate has condoned its irregularity----and I am prepared to accept that, because it seems to be a common-sense point of view - we must assume that it condoned everything up to the point when the irregularity was detected. That was 3 o'clock. Now, there is a sessional order, which was passed in a regular way, and which says that the Senate shall meet at 2.30 p.m. By an irregular motion we determined to meet at 10.30 in the morning. I am prepared to agree with you that, although we met on Wednesday morning contrary to the only sessional order which has full force and effect, the Senate has condoned that irregularity by the fact that it went on with it. The Senate itself must share the responsibility for whatever error was subsequently discovered. But having condoned the Wednesday morning sitting, it equally condoned the proceedings which took place from 2.30 to 3.30 yesterday. In fact, it condoned everything up to the point- when the error was detected- If that be so, it seems to me that the proper course would have been for the Minister to move the adjournment of the debate.
he could not. Because Senator Turley was in possession of the Chair.

You yourself suggested that Senator Turley should ask leave to continue his remarks at a subsequent period. That, I think, was the proper course to take, on the assumption that the Senate had condoned what had previously taken place. My point is that either the Senate condoned the whole of the previous proceedings or none of them. But your ruling assumes that it only condoned them up to 1 o'clock yesterday. What ought to have been done in order to break back to the regular track was for the minister to put such a motion before the Senate as would have enabled us to get back to the regular track.
That was one way out of the difficulty. But Senator Turley would not agree to that method, and I took another.
That was the sugestion of Senator Symon
The honorable senator is not always so willing to act upon a suggestion by Senator Symon.
I did not act upon it. I told the President that I thought the proper course for him to take was to call on private business at once.

I cannot reconcile the position in which we find ourselves. If the irregularity was condoned to 1 o'clock, it was condoned up to 3 o'clock. If it was condoned un to 3 o'clock. When Senator Turley was speaking to the question of the third reading, it follows that as he failed to ask permission to continue his remarks—
That was not necessary, and it was not necessary at 1 o'clock.

If we assume, sir, that you condoned the irregularity up to o'clock, why is it that it has not been condoned up to 3 o'clock? Either it was condoned from the time it began until it was detected, or it was not. There are two points at which I think it could be corrected. Either we could go back to the moment when it began, or we could go right down to the moment when it was detected, Common sense suggests that we should go down to the time when it was detected, and that was not 1 o'clock, but 3 o'clock. Therefore, either everything done up to 3 o'clock was condoned by the Senate, or nothing was condoned. You, sir, cannot arbitrarily divide the time, and say that the Senate condoned the irregularity up to one point of time, but not for the whole of the period.
What difference does it make? Senator Turley is still in possession of the Chair in reference to the Bill

It does make a difference of substance, if the Senate condoned the irregularity up to 3 o'clock, and the third reading of the Bill was then regularly before the Chair, then a motion ought to have been submitted for. the purpose of carrying the Bill properly forward, but failing that the whole, business ought to have dropped off the notice-paper.
That is all the honorable senator wants.
It is equally open to me to retort that the Minister is merely taking the opposite view, because it would facilitate the transaction of his business.
Had the point of order been raised at 11 o'clock, what would have been the position?
The position would have been exactly the same as it was at 3 o’clock. It might have been said that we had condoned all the irregularity up to Wednesday night, but not for Thursday.
The proceedings on Thursday from half past 10 to 1 o'clock were perfectly regular.
No.
That point is not raised now. I understand that Senator Neild intends to raise it on some other occasion.

However, it is not necessary for the purpose of my argument. We can get back to the regular course by one of two ways. Either we can go back to the point at which we broke away from the regular course, or we can say that we have condoned everything up to the point when the error was detected.
Hear. Hear.
That was at 3 o'clock.
When it was detected Senator Turley had no right to ask leave to continue his remarks.
The Minister assents to my proposition that we have condoned every irregularity up to 3 o'clock
I think so.
But the President's ruling is to the effect that we have only condoned the irregularity up to 1 o'clock
No.
The President has based his remarks on that view of the case. because he said that at 1 o'clock a natural suspension of the sitting took place.
I cannot see the slightest difference in the result, whether the irregularity was condoned up to 1 o'clock. or up to the time when attention was called to it.

There is an ordinary suspension of the sitting at 1 o'clock. In view of that fact, we have for one day do, and which has been applied to other days, and upon the resumption of the sitting, the business is proceeded with just as if no suspension had taken place. But no suspension at 3 o'clock, such as the suspension for lunch, is provided for. There is a sessional order which prescribes when the Senate shall suspend its business, but at 3 o’clock yesterday the position was different. Seeing that the cutting off of the business took place when the Senate was sitting, we must look to other orders to know what ought to be done. What happens when it is proposed to terminate he discussion on a measure? A motion is submitted, and that is what ought to have been done yesterday. The occurrence at 3 o'clock yesterday was not a suspension in the sense of a lunch suspension; but it was a termination of the discussion on the Bill.
Really that is not the point at issue at all. The question is that my ruling—that the Order of the Day for the third reading of a Bill was still on the notice-paper—be dissented from.
No.
What I ruled was that the Clerk was in order in calling on that Order of the Day.
And the President, if he had not been interrupted, would have called on Senator Turley to continue his remarks.
According to my copy of the notice-paper, the motion reads as follows:-

quote.para: That the President's ruling—that the third reading of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill can be taken without an adjournment of the debate, or without leave to Senator Turley to resume his speech—be dissented from.

talk.start.para: Those are Senator Clemons' reasons for dissenting from the ruling.
I am supporting those reasons, and trying to show that at 3 o'clock yesterday, when the point of order was taken—
The Bill had really dropped.
The Bill had dropped, because there was a failure on the part of someone to move that the debate be adjourned, and that, I take it, is the point which Senator Clemons has raised.
Absolutely.
If we refuse to accept that view, we cannot logically say that we condoned every irregularity up to 1 o'clock.

I do not pretend to have any close or exact knowledge of the Standing Orders, because I usually trust to the President, the Chairman of Committees, and the officials to keep the Senate straight in that regard. It appears to me that, somehow or other, we have got into a remarkable tangle. So far, we have not discovered any intelligible means of extricating ourselves from the difficulty. I admit at once that there is no precedent for a case of this kind. I suppose that we might search the history of Parliaments all over the world and fail to find an exact parallel to the position here. I listened very carefully to the remarks of Senator Millen and I think that he put the case very clearly and very fairly. He pointed out that we had condoned either everything up to 3 o'clock, or nothing. Now the Government, and you, sir, must accept one position or the other. If we condoned nothing, then the morning sitting on Wednesday was irregular.
Why?
Because the sessional order empowering the Senate to sit at 10.30 a.m., instead of at 2.30 p.m., was irregular.
That sessional order contains the words "unless otherwise ordered."
It was not otherwise ordered in proper form.
That is a different point from the one at issue, and it arises under a different sessional order.

If the irregularity has been condoned by the Senate, it has been condoned up to the moment of discovery, and that is up to 3 p.m. yesterday. By your decision, sir, you have turned the hand clock back to 1, and have acted as if the irregularity had not proceeded beyond that hour.
I do not think so.

The irregularity went on until 3 o'clock, when it was discovered that, instead of public business, private business ought to have been before the Senate. Senator Turley, who was speaking, was asked by you to resume his seat, and he did so. A little while afterwards he was asked by you whether he would request the permission of the Senate to resume his speech at a later hour of the day. Clearly you had the idea in your mind that it was necessary. in the circumstances, if the debate was to be continued, and the Bill was not to drop off the notice-paper, that he should make that request. The very fact that you requested Senator Turley to ask leave to resume his speech at a later hour of the day demonstrates to me—
I never said anything about a later hour of the day.
I do not think that you will deny that you asked Senator Turley to request permission to resume his speech.
No; that is right.
then you must have bad it in your mind at that time that it was absolutly necessary for Senator Turley to do so.
I think the honorable senator has no right to impute to me what is in my mind when he does not know.

I think, if you will excuse me, that I did not say that what I have just repeated was in your mind, but that it appeared to me from the fact that you asked Senator Turley to do so, that it was in your mind that the business could not proceed unless he did.
that was to carry on in compliance with the Standing Orders.
That was to carry an the discussion in the ordinary way. When the discussion upon a measure is interrupted in the ordinary course, that is the procedure usually followed.
In the event of a count out, for instance, the measure under discussion at the time goes off the paper.

Suppose any measure is being debated, and an arrangement is come to that some other question should be brought before the Senate, and the first dropped, for the time being, the adjournment of the debate is moved, or the honorable senator speaking asks leave to continue his remarks on a future occasion.
And the Senate makes an order as to when that business is to be resumed.
That is so. Now I come to 3 o'clock of yesterday afternoon. It was then discovered that the whole business was irregular, and Senator Turley sat down in consequence of your request.
No; on a point of order being raised.
The honorable senator did not ask leave to continue his speech on a future occasion, and no member of the Senate moved the adjournment of the debate.
No member of the Senate could do so.
In the circumstances, so far as I am able to discover, the measure drop pad off the business paper. That is certainly what would happen in the ordinary course.
No.

The President very conveniently obviates all this difficulty by wining out completely what occurred between 2.3o p.m. and 3 p.m. yesterday. He goes back to 1 p.m. and says that the debate was interrupted then. But the debate was not interrupted then. It was not interrupted until 3 p.m. by the discovery that the whole proceedings were irregular. The Senate immediately condoned what had taken place previously. Seeing that we were off the track, we decided to put ourselves on the track again, and at 3 p.m. we did so. If the discovery had been made at 1 p.m., prior to the adjournment for lunch, it would not have been necessary for Senator Turley to ask leave to resume his speech, or for anyone to move the adjournment of the debate. The honorable senator could have continued his speech in the ordinary course immediately after private members' business had been disposed of. But there was no discovery until 3 p.m., and that being the case, I contend that it was then absolutely, necessary for Senator Turley to obtain Leave to resume his speech, or for someone to move the adjournment of the debate in the ordinary way. That was not done, and I therefore submit, with all deference to you, sir, that the Bill dropped off the business paper, and must be restored in the ordinary way. To obviate the difficulty, it is not sufficient to say that the discovery took place at 1 p.m. It did not take place at that hour. The ordinary course of business was pursued up to 3 p.m. That was the moment of discovery that the proceedings had been irregular. The discussion of the Bill was interrupted then, and if it was, provision should have been made in the ordinary way for its continuance. That provision was not made, and I therefore submit again with all deference that the Bill dropped off the business-paper.

It would be courteous to the Senate and to you, sir, that I should say something in reply. Apart from my desire to comply with that duty of courtesy, my chief object in rising is io make a brief endeavour to strip from the arguments which have been used all that I think was irrelevant. If I might do so with respect, I would say first, that the case of Browne v. Cowley, which you have cited, has no application to the question before the Senate.
Very likely, but I cited the case because the point was raised by Senator Gould that the whole proceedings of yesterday morning had been invalidated.

I am glad that you recognise that I offered that remark with no disrespect to you. I come to what I consider to be the salient points connected with this matter. The usual suspension of the sitting of the Senate between x and 2 P.M. has nothing to do with the case. It was in accordance with our sessional orders, which give you power to suspend the sitting. The difficulty first arose when Senator Neild took his point of order that the whole debate on the third reading of the Bill had not been in order. If it is necessary for me to amplify that, let me say that there is no sessional order empowering the President to suspend a debate except at certain specified times, as at 1 p.m. and 6.0 p.m., when sittings of the Senate are suspended in strict conformity with orders which are sessional, but which have the same authority as Standing Orders. In my endeavour to strip away what is irrelevant to the question, let me say that the suspension of the sitting yesterday at 1 p.m. could have no relevance to it. Let me put the matter, if I can, in a nutshell. Senator Turley was speaking on the third reading of the Bill, when, for reasons which it is not necessary that I should enlarge upon, he was compelled to resume his seat, and to cease debating the motion. We discovered, in consequence of your ruling, that the debate could no longer be continued. Nothing happened as a matter of fact except that the debate was interrupted and stopped. The next proceeding was to call on other business, which was subsequently proceeded with. Then at 7.45 p.m. the point arose as to what business could be put before the Senate. You, sir, then asked the Clerk to call on the Order of the Day for the third reading of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill, and the point is whether in conformity with the Standing Orders it was possible for that order to be called on. In ordinary circumstances you will recognise that it would be possible, if, for instance, the debate had been adjourned and on motion the resumption of the debate had been made an order for 7.45 p.m.

Does the honorable senator not notice that when the point of order was taken, and the President ruled that we had no right to go on with other than private business, we could not by a motion for. the resumption of the debate have taken up Government business?

If Senator Playford seriously submits that argument, he weakens the whole case on the other side. I am willing to accept the argument and to follow it out to its proper conclusion, but I wish now to put the matter in as small a compass as possible. If the debate had been adjourned, and a time set down for its resumption, it could at that time have been continued. As we know, that was not done, and no one will dispute the facts on that point. It was not adjourned, and no time was fixed for its resumption. Another way in conformity with our Standing Orders for securing the continuance of a debate that has been stopped is for the honorable senator who is speaking to obtain leave to resume his speech when the business is next called on. That leave to resume a speech implies that the debate will be carried on at some future time. My point is that neither of those two methods for the continuance of the debate were adopted. I have been unable to discover any other method which could have been adopted. I should have been glad if in the whole of the argument, or in your ruling, there had been any indication of any other method whereby the debate in question could have been resumed in conformity with the Standing Orders. I have to remind you, sir. that you have yourself stated that there is no standing order that supplies the deficiency. You said, "I admit there is no standing order that enables us to do it." What was the position then? I admit that it was one of great difficulty for yourself and for all of us. I think you recognise that we had to depart from our Standing Orders to get out of the difficulty. I am going to suggest that there was a perfectly easy way in which we could have got out of that difficulty, as we have got out of similar difficulties. When, under the Standing Orders, we cannot do something which we think desirable, we ask leave of the Senate. There is nothing more common in the procedure of the Senate than for leave to be given in order that something may be done which we all recognise could not he done tinder the Standing Orders without that leave. Such leave was not given in this instance. I wish to emphasize the point raised by Senator Stewart and other honorable senators. You will pardon me, sir, if I attempt finally to find for you some good reason for what you have said. It is a fact that you inquired of Senator Turley if he asked leave to resume the debate. You must not, and I am sure you would not, expect any honorable senator to believe that you asked that question at random, or without some good reason. The reason is obvious to all if us. If leave had been given to Senator Turley to resume the debate, I admit at once that the position would have been different. It was not given. I must emphasize your particular request to Senator Turley to ask for that leave, because it indicated a desire, and a very proper desire, in your mind at the time to put the proceedings in ‘order. Senator Turley refused to ask for leave, and I have not the slightest doubt that it was because he felt that if he were to ask for leave to continue a speech which, according to our Standing Orders, had never been begun, he would put himself in a false position. This clearly emphasizes the fact that something was done which ought not to have been done.
That is plain enough. We should have taken private business when we took Government business.
That is not the point. The point is that leave should have been obtained for Senator Turley to resume his speech. That course has been adopted on dozens of similar occasions.
There never has been a similar occasion.

I withdraw the word "similar," but on dozens of occasions when we have been confronted with the fact that we could not do something under the Standing Orders which we wished to do, leave of the Senate has been asked and granted. You will not ask me to give instances of that kind. I suggest that that would have been a proper remedy to have applied to our difficulties, but it was not applied. For the reasons I have given, I am still of opinion that if the debate on the third reading of the Bill is now resumed it will not be resumed in accordance with the standing order.

division.result.para: Question is resolved in the negative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 20th September (vide page 4982), on motion by Senator PLAYFORD- -
That the Bill be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: I regret that there should have been so long an interruption.
Do not make a farce of it!

I have a perfect right to express my regret that my speech has been interrupted for so long a time. I have here a number of Hansard proofs, delivered to me this morning, and although, according to the decision of the Senate, I did not speak after 1 o'clock yesterday, I find I am credited with having said a great deal after that hour.
In order to make those remarks regular, they ought to be repeated.

When I showed these proofs to one honorable senator, he said that he intended to see whether he could not have the remarks eliminated from the Hansard report. That, however, would not be fair to me, and yet—
Take them as read.

A number of honorable senators are prepared to take anything as read, so long as it will assist the passage of measures in which they take a great interest. However, when I was interrupted yesterday by the point of order, I was dealing with the finances of Queensland as disclosed in the State Treasurer's tables laid before the Parliament of that State. I had shown that the railways of Western Australia were returning a considerable profit, after paying of working expenses, interest, and other charges, and was quoting figures to prove that, on the contrary, the Queensland people each year had to contribute large sums out of the Consolidated Revenue in order to meet the deficiency in the railway finances. In the year ending 30th June, 1901-2, the interest on expenditure in connexion with the railways of Queensland amounted to £837,205, and the net income, after paying working expenses, interest, and so forth, to £324,077, leaving a deficiency to be made up Out of the Consolidated Revenue of £513,128; in 1902-3 the interest was £859,986, and the net income £382,532, leaving a deficiency of £477,454; in 1903-4 the interest was £873,006, and the net income £485,009, leaving a deficiency Of £387,997; in 1904-5 the interest was £876,568, and the net income £59 ,670, leaving a deficiency of £281,897; in 1905-6 the interest was £81,414, and the net income £671,524, leaving a deficiency Of £209,890. The annual increase in the interest bill will be observed. These deficiencies are altogether apart from depreciation; and incidental to the raising of new loans, there has been a great deal of expenditure, a proportion of which should properly be debited to the railways. I wonder 'whether honorable senators who are supporting the Bill have ever realized how the Queensland Government have to dip into the pockets of the taxpayers—not only those who use the railways, but the taxpayers generally—in order to maintain the railway system. In addition, we have now to find the necessary money for railway extension by adding to the burdens of the taxpayers, with the object of developing our own territory, and the Consolidated Revenue has to be resorted to continually for the purpose of maintaining in a state of efficiency the railway communication between Sydney and Brisbane. It is not a fair thing that those people should have to put their hands further into their pockets to pay for the construction of railways for the wealthy State of Western Australia. We ask that they shall develop their own territory, as we have developed ours. The opinion has been expressed by competent persons who have seen the country which it is proposed shall be traversed by this railway, that the expenditure of the money would not be wise. It seems to me that we should be flying in the face of Providence and acting against the best interests of all the States if we were to consent to throw money away on the project.

My objections to this measure may be divided under three heads. The first is that the Commonwealth has no: a Railway Department to manage the line, if it be constructed it will inevitably mean the creation of a new Commonwealth Department; and it is -worthy of consideration whether we ought to undertake work in connexion with railways until we establish a thorough railway policy of our own. That would not be a reasonable thing to do unless the whole of the railways of the States were handed over to the Federal Government. Another objection to the project is suggested to me by the fact that I represent a State which is seriously hampered because it has not sufficient money at its command to enter upon a policy of railway construction for the benefit of its own people. There are portions of Tasmania where the land is rich, and the settlers are of the best kind, but the people suffer intense hardships from the lack of railways and roads. The State cannot afford to construct railways, although in many parts they are urgently needed.
I beg, sir, to draw your attention to the state of the Senate. [Quorum formed.]

It was simply because the second reading of the Bill was so unexpectedly carried that many honorable senators feel themselves quite justified in opposing its third reading. In many portions of Tasmania, a railway is required, but the Minister of Railways has told the House of Assinb1y that during the next year the Government do not propose to spend any money upon railway construction. Although it is generally recognised by a majority in the Tasmanian Parliament that in the interests of the State the construction of certain railways is necessary, still, they cannot afford to provide railway communication, and thus enable very good land in remote districts to be brought under cultivation. In those circumstances, is it surprising that the residents of those districts regard with great disfavour a proposal to expend £20,000 of Commonwealth money in linking up two States who would derive the main benefit from the construction of the railway? No one can really blame the taxpayers of Tasmania for condemning the construction of the railway, especially as it would come under the head of a new work, and, therefore, would be charged on a per capita basis. It is very unfair, I think, that the proposed expenditure of £20,000 should be incurred while the present system of distributing the revenue is maintained. If the representatives of Western Australia could show me that, in the interests of the Commonwealth, a defence work or a post-office was necessary for the proper maintenance and continuance of the transferred Departments, I should offer no objection, because it has been laid down by constitutional authorities that the expenditure on all new works, even in connexion with transferred Departments, must be distributed on a. per capita basis. There are two classes of new works, those which may be held to be necessary, such as defence works, and those which by the greatest stretch of imagination cannot be held to he necessary, and the proposals now before the Senate come within the latter category. It is unfair and un-Federal to the taxpayers of the State I represent to ask them to contribute one penny towards the cost of this survey when we know that later on the supporters of the scheme will claim that the Commonwealth is committed to the construction of the line. I have entered my final protest against the proposal, because I have considered it my duty to do so; and I trust, even at this late stage, that the measure will not be allowed to pass.

If we were not aware of what occurs beyond the four walls of the Chamber, I might very well ask the object of the weary addresses to which we have been treated. After the prolonged debate on the preceding stages of the measure, we might have expected that there would be a very short debate on the third reading. We have been told that the speeches made on the later stages of the Bill are in the nature of protests, but as protests they come altogether too late. They would be worthy of some consideration if they had been made six or seven years ago, at the time when the promises were made and published throughout the Commonwealth that if Western Australia came into the Federation the transcontinental railway would be constructed. I challenge any opponent of this great national scheme to point to any protests that were seriously made and entertained at the time the promises were made. The people of Western Australia were led to believe that with Federation nothing would be surer, and few things earlier of accomplishment, than the transcontinental railway, and they were warned in solemn phrases that if they were foolish enough to stand out of the Federation, and did not weigh well the advantage of entering it, nothing would be more certain than that they would lose the opportunity of having this railway constructed at an early date. It may well be believed that those of us who favoured Federation in Western Australia took care that as much publicity as possible should be given to the promises of men of standing in the Federal movement. The present Prime Minister was one of the Colonial delegates to the old country to watch the passage of the Constitution Act through the Imperial Parliament, and on his return he publicly stated, quite apart from the concession of the special Tariff, that he was able to say, from private conversations with other members of the Convention, that, if a request had been made by Western Australian delegates that provision should be made in black and white in the Constitution for the construction of the railway, it would have been complied with by the Convention. Mr. Kingston, another of the delegates to England, was pledged up to the hilt to this railway scheme. He gave such clear and explicit promises on this question that there could be no doubt about them; and that was known all over Australia. The protests, of which we have heard so much during the last week or two, should have been entered when men of standing like Mr. Deakin and Mr. Kingston were making these promises. But never a word was uttered against them. I have taken the trouble to inquire if in any public utterance any of the men who are prominent in the Federal Parliament to-day ever raised any objection to the promises made by leading Federalists at that time, and I cannot find a single word.
The honorable senator will hear more about it before he is much older.

I dare say we shall’ but I should have preferred, in the interests of honest dealing, and in order that the people of Western Australia might not have been deceived and cajoled into entering the Federation under false pretences –
I rise to a point of order. The honorable senator says that the State of Western Australia has been deceived and cajoled into entering the Federation under false pretences.
that is not a point of order; although the remark may have been an improper one.
Senator de Largie must know that it is grossly innacurate.

I think the honorable senator must be fishing for something which will enable him to find fault with what I say. What I said was that I thought the protests we now bear should have been uttered years ago, when the promises were made, in order that the people of Western Australia might have been in no way deceived, and might have known exactly the conditions of which they would enter the Federation, and whether there would be any opposition to the scheme we are now discussing. I should have expected Senator Dobson to then raise his voice in protest against it – I know that when the promises I have mentioned were replaced at Albany by Mr. Deakin, Mr. Henry, a prominent Tasmanian who was present, hear-heard every statement of the Prime Minister; feeling in Tasmania. The protest of Senator Dobson, and those who think with him, are six years too late, and are of such a character as to entitle them to no weight. Had the Western Australian people had the slightest suspicion that there was the remotest probability of any of the states opposing the construction of transcontinental line, they would have remained outside of Federation. At that time Western Australia was in such a position that in a sense it could have compelled the other states to consent to the construction of the railway as a condition of Federation. What sort of commonwealth would this have been if Western Australia, representing one-third of the Continent, and remained outside the Union? Western Australia at that time was just beginning its national life and with its vast underdeveloped resources, might have looked forward with every hope too becoming a wealthy and self-contained country. The great deposits of gold had just been tapped; and it would have been possible to apply protectionists principles and encourage industries to the level of those conducted in the same cast. Today, of course, Western Australia is in a very different positional and, with border protection impossible, cannot, in view of the higher rates of wages there prevailing, hope to compete with the old-established industries in the eastern States. The protest of Senator Dobson and his friends are not only too late, but most unfair to a state which was absolutely coaxed into the federation. It is unjust for the eastern States to now turn around and say “were we made those promises when you were free and independent and could not act as you pleased. In our own best interests, but now that you are in the snare, we will exercise what power we have to render those promises abortive.” Let me say, how3ever, that Western Australia is not such a helpless position as some honorable senators may think. For some time past, the debate has been going on in the Western Australian Parliament; and those who are now opposing this Bill could not, if the tried to do the session movement in Western Australia.
Does the honorable senator think that the Western Australian people would secede on this one question?

I am not prepared to answer for Western Australia; I speak for myself. I am merely now, when a grievous wrong is likely to be perpetrated, pointing out the danger of the step which senator O’Keefe, and those who think with him, are about to take. I thought it only right to make these observations in order that the true position may be known to those who are about to vote against the third reading of the Bill, and who, by doing so, are evading and repudiating the solemn promise made to Western Australian prior to Federation.

The proposal that the Commonwealth should enter on a policy of railway construction is so important that it ought not to be hastily adopted. The Constitution, no doubt, gives the Commonwealth power, within certain limitations, to enter upon a policy of that character, but I do not think that the people of Australia ever contemplated that the business of railway construction and owning would be undertaken by the Commonwealth without very serious consideration. Before setting forth on such an enterprise, it might be desirable to take a referendum of the people of Australia, to find out whether they are willing to invest their money in a commercial undertaking of the kind—whether they are inclined to so expand the functions of the Commonwealth Government. No attempt has been made to ascertain the opinion of the people on the question, and I consider it to be my duty, as one of the guardians appointed to look after the rights and interests of Queensland in this Senate, to do all I can to obstruct this policy until we have the direct sanction of the people. As has been pointed out, the Constitution is very clear with regard to railway construction and acquisition. We can neither acquire railways already constructed nor build railways without the consent of the State affected. That consent has not been given by South Australia in this case—a fact which is of sufficient importance to warrant me in voting against the third reading of the Bill. When South Australia has been requested to give her consent, she has evaded the question, or has absolutely refused. Under these circumstances, I really do not see how even the representatives of South Australia can conscientiously vote for the Bill.
I draw attention to the absence of a quorum. [Quorum formed.]

Of course, I am not the keeper of the political consciences of the honorable senators to whom I have referred, but, still, the fact remains that while they are willing that the Commonwealth shall spend £20,000 or any other um which may be necessary for this survey, a portion of the money being expended in their territory, there is not the slightest doubt that their State will not agree to the railway being constructed, even after the surrey is made.
That is mere assumption.
Of course, I have no direct evidence, but there is a quantity of circumstantial evidence which points directly to the fact I have indicated.
What evidence?
The utterances of South Australian public men, and the attitude of the representatives of that State, both in the Senate and in another place.
Who are they?

We have heard the leader of the Senate, who is a South Australian, say deliberately on the floor of this Chamber that he himself was opposed to the building of the railway, and did not think that South Australia would ever consent to it.
I never said any such thing. It is not true.
The honorable senator must not say that. He must withdraw that statement.
I only alluded to what Senator Stewart said about me. I will withdraw it if it is necessary to do so, but that will not take away the effect of my denial.
That is not a, proper way to withdraw a statement. The honorable senator asserted that Senator Stewart had made a statement that was untrue. I call upon him to withdraw it.
I withdraw it, sir, but, nevertheless, the honorable senator's statement was incorrect.

I am extremely sorry if I have misrepresented Senator P!ayford, and apologize to him; but I distinctly remember him saying something which led me to the conclusion that I have indicated. However, I need not labour the point. We know perfectly well that the South Australian public is opposed to the building of the line, and the South Australian Government dare not even ask its Parliament for permission.
I doubt that statement very much.

I ask Senator McGregor why a Bill has not been passed to authorize the survey The various Premiers of South Australia have always known that such permission was necessary. They have been asked on several occasions by Prime Ministers of the Commonwealth for the consent of their State. They have been asked by Sir Edmund Barton, by Mr. Alfred Deakin, and by Mr. Watson.
And they always gave it.

On each occasion they have evaded giving the consent required. I am driven to the conclusion that, while the Premiers of South Australia may have been willing to give an unofficial sanction to the survey, they were so much afraid of hostile public opinion that they dare not ask their Parliament to give its consent.
If the honorable senator thought that he would not say another word.
I am sorry to say that I do think it.
The Premier of South Australia made a declaration in consequence of an amendment carried last year at the instance of Senator Givens.
Declarations are mere things of air.
From a labour Premier?

I do not care whether they come from a labour Premier, a capitalistic Premier, or any other Premier. Such a declaration is of no value to me, unless the Premier is prepared to embody it in an Act of Parliament.
Vote for this, and it will be in an Act of Parliament.
Very well, I shall let the honorable senator have an opportunity to vote for the third reading of the Bill. I intend to vote against it.

division.header.para: Question—That the Bill be now read a third time—put. The Senate divided.

talk.start.para: I challenge the vote of Senator Fraser. He is paired with Senator Symon.
No, I am not paired.
Senator Symon has a pair.
I challenge the vote of Senator Fraser. He is paired with Senator Symon.
Order!

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

quote.para: That Government business, Orders of the Day Nos. 2 to 9, be Orders of the Day for the next day of sitting.

talk.start.para: I move-

quote.para: That, unless otherwise ordered, in addition to the days of meeting set forth in sessional orders of the 14th June and the 17th August, Monday of each week be a meeting day of the Senate during the remainder of the present session, the hour of meeting to be 3 p.m., and that on such day Government business take precedence of all other business on the notice-paper, except questions and formal motions, and that, unless otherwise ordered, the time of meeting of the Senate on Tuesdays be 110.30 a.m., and that on such day Government business take precedence of all other business on the notice-paper except questions and formal motions.

talk.start.para: According to standing order 120, the motion cannot be moved.
Why not?

Because the Orders of the Day have been called on, and those have to take precedence. Although the honorable senator has moved the Orders of the Day off the notice-paper, that will not enable him to bring on the notices of motion.
It has been done over and over again. It is only a question of precedence.

It has been done constantly. I ask honorable senators especially those who have been lecturing me for not getting on with business, and providing sufficient time, to give another sitting day to the Government, and thus provide themselves with more time in which to discuss exceedingly important measures.
But when is the session going to end?
I cannot tell the honorable senator.

I rise to a point of order. I take it, sir, that under standing order 127 this is distinctly a motion of a character which requires seven days' notice to be given. It is provided by sessional order of 14th June—

quote.para: That the days of meeting of the Senate during the present session be Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of each week—

interjection.para: It was distinctly provided that for the whole of the session there were to be three meeting days, and, necessarily, honorable senators made their business arrangements in order to be free to attend on those days

talk.start.para: We altered that sessional order so as to include Tuesday.

The Minister will find that I have not overlooked that point. On the 14th June the Senate, after appointing three sitting days during the present session, prescribed how those days were to be used. Perhaps I had better read the session order—

quote.para: That the days of meeting of the Senate during the present session be Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of each week, at the hour of half-past two o'clock in the afternoon of Wednesday and Thursday, and at the hour of half-past ten o'clock in the forenoon of Friday, unless otherwise ordered.

talk.start.para: Clearly the words "unless otherwise ordered" referred to the hours of meeting.
That is the point.

With a little regard for, and I hope a little knowledge of the construction of the English language and rules of punctuation, I submit that the words "unless otherwise ordered" have peculiar applicability to the Friday sitting, and to that only. If those words were intended to govern the whole paragraph, I submit that they would have been used at the commencement, and not at the end. All that is aimed at in the sessional order is to fix the days of sitting and the hours of meeting, and I submit that it is scarcely possible to say that the words "unless otherwise ordered" apply to the first part of the sentence. I would point out that the next sessional order, No. 13, is a mere elaboration of the previous one. It relates to the hours and the disposal of business, and as you, sir, said yesterday, the words "unless otherwise ordered" do not appear therein. On the 17th August—and I take it that my objection to the present motion really applies to what was done on that date—an additional sitting day was appointed, and it is so described in the resolution. The present motion sets out Monday as an additional day of sitting. Clearly, these additional days of sitting cannot be covered by the mere phrase "unless otherwise ordered," which follows upon the hours of sitting. If you, sir, were to take that view, it would be quite futile for us to fix the days of sitting, because the Minister could then submit a motion when honorable senators were scattered over the Commonwealth. If by simply giving one day's notice additional sitting days could be taken, the business of the Senate would be carried on in the ignorance of those who were away. Seeing that many honorable senators are not resident in Melbourne, but that their homes are scattered about the Commonwealth, I take it that the object of the seven days' notice provided for in standing order 127 was to give every honorable senator a chance to know what business was coming on. If we can have sitting days ordered not in accordance with that standing order—
That only refers to the rescission of a resolution.
Does it not also involve the alteration of a resolution? I think that it involves the whole question. It reads—

quote.para: An order, resolution, or other vote of the Senate may be rescinded; but no such orders, resolution, or other vote may be rescinded during the same session, unless seven days' notice be given, and at least one-half of the whole number of senators vote in favour of its rescission.
