Provided that to correct irregularities or mistakes one day's notice only shall be sufficient.

talk.start.para: I see that that might be against my argument; but I ask you, sir, whether it is not practically a rescission of the resolution of the 14th June to add new sitting days practically without notice, after it had been laid down that the sitting days for the session should be such as are set out in that sessional order. If the motion proposed to reduce the number of sitting days, you would certainly say that it was a rescission. Can we say that to increase the number of days is not equally a rescission? Although the Point is not 50 absolutely clear as I should like it to be, I shall not labour the argument further, but shall sum it up in this proposition: That to reduce the number of sitting days would undoubtedly be a rescission in part of the order of the 14th June, and therefore by parity of reasoning to add to the number of sitting days is actually a rescission in part of that order.

I shall give my ruling, and shall then rule out of order any honorable senator who wishes to speak on the point afterwards, unless, of course, lie desires to dispute the ruling. The ordinary practice of Parliaments and of the Senate has always been to fix a certain number of days for sitting at the commencement of a session, and to increase that number towards the end of the session. The point taken is that, by the wording of order No. 12. made on the 14th June, we are prevented from doing that in this instance, except by rescinding that order and making another. That I understand to be the point; if it is not I do not know what it is. The first question that arises is, what did the order of the 14th Jun mean? It reads—

quote.para: That the days of meeting of the Senate during the present session be Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of each week, at the hour of half-past 2 o'clock in the afternoon of Wednesday and Thursday, and at the hour of half-past 10 o'clock in the forenoon of Friday, unless otherwise ordered.

continue.para: These words, "unless otherwise ordered," apply- to the whole resolution. I admit that the contention which Senator Neild sets tip is possible, but I also think that the contention that the words are to be applied to the whole resolution is also possible, and that that is what the Senate intended. If that be so, there is nothing in the point raised by the honorable senator. As to the wisdom of that contention, I would ask honorable senators to consider why the words "unless otherwise ordered" were included in the order if it was intended that they should be applied only to Friday. The Senate has already confirmed that construction of the sessional order by agreeing to the order of the 17th August. In that order the days of meeting were altered by the Senate, and no question was raised. I think the broadest and most comprehensive meaning should be given to the resolution of the 14th June. There is another point to be considered. Were it not for standing orders Nos. 126 and 127 we could from time to time alter our resolutions, and we should be in the position of having two resolutions, one in conflict with the other, when the latter would, of course, prevail. That is a contention which was raised the other day. Undoubtedly that would be so if it were not for our standing orders 126 and 127. Standing order 126 reads—

quote.para: No question or amendment shall be proposed which is the same in substance as any question or amendment which in the same session has been resolved in the affirmative or negatived, unless the order, resolution, or vote on such question or amendment has been rescinded.

continue.para: The next standing order provides the method by which it can be rescinded. I ruled the other day that the resolution which we passed on the 11th September was ineffectual, because it absolutely contradicted the resolution which we passed on the 1 4th June and the first resolution had not been rescinded, and did not contain the words "until otherwise ordered." That was resolution No. 13 of the 14th June, and the resolution- to which we are now referring is another resolution altogether, No. 12 of the 14th June. In my opinion the meaning and intention of the Senate was to provide that the ordinary practice might be followed, namely, that we should increase the number of sitting days at the end of the session, and therefore that we meant the words "unless otherwise ordered" to apply to the whole resolution. Before putting the motion, I should like to say a word or two if I may be permitted to do so- I am going to vote against it, and I hope that it will not be carried. I am speaking from my own point of view, and I say that we have had very hard work during this week, and, at all events, should have next Monday, even though we sit on Mondays after that date.

talk.start.para: I have no obfection to the motion if the Government think it necessary.
I think it absolutly necessary.
But I wish to put in a plea for private members business.
It will come on as a matter of course every Thursday now at 2.30 p.m.

It is possible that there will be only one more Thursday in the session, and there is one Bill in the name of a private member of the Senate which, unless an opportunity is afforded to pass it this session, it will be useless to proceed with for the next three years.
Why did not the honorable senator think of that when he was "stone-walling" the other Bill?

I did not occupy twenty minutes on the Bill referred to. Owing to the importance which other honorable senators as well as myself attach to the Bill to which I. now refer, I think we ought to be given an opportunity to take action in connexion with it. I therefore move—

quote.para: That after the word "motions," line 9, the following words be inserted —"and except that private members' Bills already on the notice-paper take precedence of all other business after 6.30 p.m. on that day.

talk.start.para: Private members are being asked to meet On Monday to help to transact Government business, and it is not too much for them to ask that the Government should give them an opportunity to forward the business they have in hand.
This would rescind the sessional order of the 14th June.
The motion fixes a new day altogether, and I think the amendment is in order.

division.header.para: Question—That the' words proposed to' he inserted be inserted—put. The Senate divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: KALGOORLIE TO PORT AUGUSTA RAILWAY SURVEY BILL: PAIRS

quote.para: that the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: I should like to speak with all calmness, although I confess I find it extremely difficult to do so. The vote that was taken this afternoon, on the motion for the third reading of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill, unless I am under a very great misapprehension, constitutes one of the greatest breathes of the word of honour of honorable men of which I have ever had experience.
The honorable senator must not reflect on a vote of the Senate.

I am not reflecting on a vote of the Senate, but on statements made in my hearing and in the hearing of others—statements on which I absolutely retied, and which were 'lever altered or retracted, but which, in view of what has occurred, have been absolutely "gone back on" in the most flagrant manner. I do not desire to impugn anybody's word, but to state the facts just as, to my mind, they occurred; and I think I shall be supported by the recollection of others. On Wednesday a compromise in regard to the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill was arrived at by which, on Senator Givens' amendment being accepted, it was agreed that the Bill should be allowed to go to the third reading on the following day. Owing to some heated remarks which passed, Senator Millen announced that he would not be a party to that agreement. That was, so far as it had been arrived at on the floor of the House. I desire Senator Clemons' attention, because I wish to state something that passed between him, the leader of the Government, and myself. During the dinner adjournment, Senator Clemons, the leader of the Government, and myself were endeavouring to arrive at an arrangement.
What date?

That was on the Wednesday. We were endeavouring to arrive at something as nearly approaching a compromise as was possible under the circumstances. Senator Clemons had up to that time been one of the most active in trying to arrive at a compromise, and he told us that, while he could not vouch for the great bulk of honorable senators on that side - because Senator Givens and others would not be a party to the agreement - he was prepared to meet us in a certain way. Senator Symon was here at the time, but he wished to go away on the following day; and Senator Clemons said that he would be prepared to assure us of a pair for Senator Symon, and that he would use his influence with senators on the other side, so far as he could, to have a straight-out debate and vote on the third reading. In the hearing of Senator Smith, Senator Clemons said that he believed he would be able to give Senator Fraser as a pair for Senator Symon, and that, if Senator Fraser would not pair, he, Senator Clemons himself, would pair with Senator Symon.
Senator Clemons said that in the Senate.

That was said by Senator Clemons in my hearing, and in the hearing of Senator Smith, while Senator Clemons was sitting alongside Senator Playford. I said to Senator Clemons, "Then we are to understand that you will pair Senator Fraser with Senator Symon, or you will pair with Senator Symon yourself," and he replied " Yes."
This was all on the one day?
So far as my memory goes, it was while we were sitting here on the Wednesday.
It was on the one day?
It was on the one day. It was the evening after the compromise had partially been arrived at from which Senator Millen broke away.
What?
It was the evening when we arrived at the compromise dissolved by the breaking away of Senator Millen.
Do you say it was before or after the compromise was broken?
It was after.
What?
It was after the compromise which bound all honorable senators on that side to come to a third reading vote, and which also incidentally secured a pair for Senator Symon.
I allowed the adjournment until the next day on the understanding that we had got a pair.

I do not wish to be misunderstood. I admit freely and frankly that the first compromise fell to the ground. But there were subsequent negotiations with Senator Clemons, and the only understanding was that, although Senator Clemons could not bind senators on the other side, he would use his influence to bring about a straight-out vote, and, further, that he would secure Senator Fraser as a pair for Senator Symon, or, in the alternative, pair himself with Senator Symon; no other honorable senator was mentioned as a pair for Senator Symon. Throughout this debate, I have been acting as the representative on this side in the matter of pairs, both with the consent of the Government, and with the consent of the Western Australian senators. It is a matter of courtesy observed by all parliamentarians that in the matter of pairs all arrangements are-made b two men who are looked to as responsible on either side of the Chamber. From that time onward, I considered that either Senator Fraser or Senator Clemons was to be paired with Senator Symon. On the morning of the next day, in the clubroom of the Senate, I asked Senator Symon. "You have secured that pair?" and he replied, "Yes, I am paired." I ask the Senate to remember that on Thursday Senator Symon told me that he was paired.
He said it in the afternoon again.

On the Thursday evening, after Senator Symon haff left for Adelaide, it had a conversation with Senator Trenwith, who told me that he was paired with Senator Gray for Thursday. I asked Senator Trenwith, "What about to-morrow, Friday?" and he replied, I have not been able to secure a pair for tomorrow." I said, "Will not Senator Gray extend his pair with you for Friday?" and Senator Trenwith replied, "I am willing, if you can get Senator Gray to prolong the pair." I then said to Senator Trenwith—and the honorable senator left Melbourne with this in his mind—" I shall make it my business to-morrow to see Senator Gray and secure an extension of that pair with you." In pursuance of that promise, I to-day rang up Senator Gray no less than three times on the telephone, and I made it my business to go and see him at the railway station. I have in my pocket at the present time his authority to pair him with Senator Trenwith. First of all—with whom is Senator Symon paired? I have been told indirectly, as coming from members on the Opposition side, that Senator Symon is paired with Senator Trenwith. If that be the case, how comes it that Senator Symon told me on Thursday that he was paired, and that at that time Senator Trenwith was paired with Senator Gray, and the former told me that he had not been paired for the Friday? Furthermore, what about Senator Fraser's part in this drama? This afternoon Senator Fraser was asked by Senator Findley if he was paired, and, in reply to the direct question, Senator Fraser said, " Yes." Senator Findley then said to Senator Fraser, "it will be an all-night sitting, I think," and Senator Fraser replied, "Well, I will not be here all night anyhow." That happened this afternoon 'within a couple of hours of the vote being taken, and Senator Fraser gave Senator Findley—who will be able to speak as to the matter--to understand that he was paired. With whom was Senator Fraser paired? All the evidence Points to the fact that up to that time Senator Fraser and Senator Symon were paired. The understanding, so far as understandings in these matters are observed, certainly was that Senator Symon was to be Paired throughout with Senator Fraser, or in the alternative of Senator Fraser declining, with Senator Clemens. - What is to become of parliamentary courtesy? If an alteration of a pair is to take place, surely the least that can be done is to acquaint those on the opposite side with the fact.
The honorable, senator did not take that view in reference to my pair.
I ask that Senator Pearce not be long, because, after all, this is a private matter.
But when the honour of a member of the Senate is involved, I say that it is a public matter.
The Senate takes no cognizance of pairs.

That may he so; but the position is that I saw Senator Gray, and he left the city after having given me authority to pair him with Senator Trenwith. If honorable senators opposite had acted in a fair, straightforward, and honorable way, a vote would not have been lost. In the debate on the Bill they have been emptying the vials of their indignation on honorable senators on this side—
I ask the honorable senator not to refer to a former debate.

I know I am limited in that respect, and I have every desire to observe the standing order; but I must say that such conduct as we have witnessed this afternoon deserves the severest reprehension of every man who likes straight dealing and fair voting. We are prepared at any time to accept defeat on fair lines, but we Cannot admit defeat on such lines as have been adopted in this particular case. I give way to honorable senators opposite when it comes to dealings such as they have been implicated in this afternoon; but it certainly reflects not to their credit, but to their discredit, and it will reflect to the discredit of the Senate if proceedings of the kind are tolerated.
—Although this debate may be out of order—
I think it is all out of order, but these seems to be so much feeling that I do not like to interrupt the honorable senator.
I shall not add to that feeling, sir, I give you my word.
The honorable senator has been attacked, and has a right to reply.
So far as I have seen attacked, I wish to tell the Senate that I have done nothing whatever that is not scrupulously just and honorable so far as the question of flairs is concerned.
Does the honorable senator throw the blame on Senator Fraser?
I do not throw the blame on any one, because I say that no blame can rightly attach to any single member of the party who voted against the third reading of the Railway Survey Bill.
The honorable senator is on his trial.

That is a most objectionable remark, which it is scarcely necessary for me to repudiate. I heard Senator de Largie say that I am on my trial. I am on no trial; but as accusations have been made against me, I suppose it is proper that I should take some notice of them.
The honorable senator is on his defence.

I have no defence to make at all. I suppose it will be admitted that Senator Symon expressed his intention to vote for the third reading of the Railway Survey Bill, and that Senator Trenwith expressed his intention to vote against it. Is either of those statements objected to by any honorable senator? Seeing that there is complete silence when I ask this simple question, I may take it that the remark is not challenged.
Did those honorable senators authorize Senator Clemons to pair them?

No. But I say to every member of the Senate who is listening that we all know how they intend to vote. We all know that Senator Symon’s intention was to vote for the third reading of the Bill, and that Senator Trenwith’s intention was to vote against hit. If those are facts, as I say they are, there is nothing more to be said.
Senator Trenwith said distinctly that he was going to vote against "stone-walling.”
This is a personal matter, and I think it is only fair to allow both sides to be heard. I therefore ask honorable senators not to interject.
I have nearly completed my statement.
What about Senator Gray?

With regard to the attitude of Senator Gray, so far as I am concerned, I am perfectly blameless. I have done nothing that was not strictly honorable, but if further information is required on that point, in the absence of Senator Gray, I must merely ask Senator Pearce, or any other honorable senator who wishes to do so, to probe the matter deeper.
I am not concerned about Senator Gray, but about Senator Symon and Senator Trenwith.

I will come to another point, and will try not to speak with any heat upon it. So far as any pledge is concerned, I have justly and scrupulously carried out any that I gave. With regard to Senator Symon's pair, I gave a pledge on the subject when we were endeavouring to effect a compromise, that if that compromise had continued, I would go so far as to make a pair with Senator Symon, But that arrangement, which I did my best to bring about, I did my best to bring about, was broken, and disappeared.
I said so

I am glad that Senator Pearce has not misrepresented me in that. To that extent, and no further, to any extent, or to any conceivable way, was I pledged to give Senator Symon a pair. I have finished. The Senate can easily see what happened. On may occasions – I might almost say thirty or forty occasions – during this debate, pairs have been transferred at the will of the senators who were pairing from time to time. I have nothing further to add.
Was not the pair I have mentioned, transferred? Will not the honorable senators answer that?
I have nothing to add except – and Senator Pearce can accept my word or not – to state deliberately that I have done nothing in this matter that has not been scrupulously honorable
May I make a statement with regard to this matter?
The honorable senator's name was not mentioned in connextion with it.
It was mentioned by Senator Pearce, and I think that I have a right to speak.
No good can happen from prolonging this discussion. Nothing can arise except angry feeling. I hope that the honorable senator will say nothing more.
I ask the Senate to allow me to speak, seeing that my name has been mentioned.
I ask that the honorable senator not to continue.
But I wish to speak.
I do not think that the honorable senator is taking a very wise course.
If the debate is to become general, it must be understood that other honorable senators will have the right to speak.
We may have twenty more speakers.
But I claim the right to speech.
I allowed Senator Pearce to make the statement that he did, and Senator Clemons to reply, but now I think that the matter had better drop. The continuance of the debate will do no good whatever
But I must ask the Senate to allow me to say a word or two.
Why?
Because my name has been mentioned. It is of no use for honorable senators opposite to try and bully me, because I am going to speak.
No accusation has been made against the honorable senator.
Any senator can speak on any subject on the motion for the adjournment.
He can speak on any public subject but the continuance of this discussion is, I think, really a great mistake. I think that it would be wise for Senator Smith not to proceed.
This is a question that affects that affects the loss of a very important Bill, and one that affects the honour of the Senate.
No, not the honour of the Senate; the conduct of certain senators has been attacked, that is all.
I will relate what I know about the matter. When Senator Symon left yesterday, I was sitting in the Chamber, and Senator Clemons came up and said-----
On a point of order—a fresh charge is being made against Senator Clemons, who has already spoken, and cannot speak again. He therefore will not have the right to reply to the charge.

I do not know what Senator Smith is going to say, and therefore I do not know whether he intends to make fresh charges against anybody. I think the wisest course would be for him not to say anything more.
I shall have to ask the Senate to allow me to proceed.
May I point out that the Standing Orders enable an honorable senator to speak to the motion for the adjournment of the Senate?
The question is whether a private arrangement between senators should be discussed in the Senate.
But it is an arrangement between public men.

When Senator Symon left yesterday, Senator Playford stated that he would agree to an adjournment providing that a pair was given to Senator Symon. Senator Clemons then stated to Senator Pearce and to the Minister that he would agree that a pair should be granted to Senator Symon. Senator Pearce added, "Will you pair him right through?" and Senator Clemons said, "Yes." What I wish to point out is that Senator Clemons had agreed to pair Senator Symon. Senator Clemons, in speaking just now, said, " I 'have to put two positions; one is that Senator Trenwith was against the Bill, and the other that Senator Symon was in favour of the Bill; therefore there is nothing dishonorable in what I have done." But what I wish to ask is this: Did Senator Trenwith desire that Senator Clemons should pair Senator Symon with him? I think that Senator Clemons should tell the Senate whether he was authorized to pair Senator Trenwith, who was already Paired. If Senator Trenwith authorized Senator Clemons to pair him with Senator Symon we ought to be told. Senator Trenwith told Senator Pearce that he would be agreeable to pair with Senator Gray if Senator Gray agreed. Senator Pearce got a statement from Senator Gray in writing that he was willing to pair with Senator Trenwith. Therefore both those honorable senators were paired. The position is this—Senator Trenwith has been paired with two senators. He authorized Senator Pearce to pair him. All that I ask of Senator Clemens is that he shall state—because I consider that the honour of the Senate is at stake—whether Senator Trenwith authorized him to pair him with Senator Symon?

I am rather amused at this tremendous display of indignation over a practice which has been followed by the honorable senators who protest against it. A man who in this fashion raises a question of honour is to all intents and purposes, like those who enter an equity Court; and we all know that those who go there must go with clean hands. The indignation and the protests of honorable senators who carried the second reading of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill by means of a transferred pair from Senator Neild to Senator Gray are hardly justifiable in reference to a transferred pair on the present occasion. Was there any protest then? Did Senator Pearce draw the attention of the Senate to what he regarded as disgraceful and dishonorable conduct on that occasion? No. He profited by the transference of a pair then; he carried the second reading of his Bill by means of it.
If that was wrong, I suppose that the honorable senator means that two wrongs make a right?

I am complaining that Senator Pearce on that occasion profited by the transferred pair, and said nothing. If there is anything in his display of virtue now, I test it by what he did on the previous occasion. I say that he remained silent and allowed the second reading of this Bill to be carried by a procedure that he now condemns. How was it carried? It was carried by means of a pair of transferred from Senator Pulsford to Senator Gray. There can be no doubt about Senator Neild’s pair on the occasion, because it is entered in the pair book as “pair for the second reading.”
By the other party to the pair. Did he have anything to say in the trickery to-day?

Did Senator Neild have anything to say? He was not here, and was not consulted, but by an arbitrary act on the part of Senator Pulsford the pair was transferred, without authority, from Senator Neild to Senator Gray.
He denied that on the floor of the senate.
I am not saying whether a transfer in that way is right or wrong. All I say is that it is too late in the day for honorable senators opposite to come here as the champions of virtue.
We had nothing to do with that pair.
No; but honorable senators profited by the pair, and did not utter a protest; nor did we squeal because we suffered. We took our “licking” in a way which they have yet to learn.
I cannot permit steps if honorable senators will not conform to the Standing Orders. The place is getting like a bear-garden.
Mr President -
The honorable senator's name has not been mentioned.

Whether my name has been mentioned or not, I claim the right to speak on behalf of a state which has been deliberately tricked by acts of which men ought to be ashamed, and to make a protest at this stage.

I think, sir, that every honorable senator will sympathize with you in the position into which you have been forced during the last few days. I can realize that it has been a very trying time indeed for you; and remembering the strain to which you have been subjected, any little exhibition of irritability is quite pardonable in the circumstances. I make that observation, because I feel that I am taking up a rather strong attitude in declining to comply with your request not to speak at this juncture.
My only object in making the request was to prevent the ventilation of a number of greivances, and so on, which had better not take place before the public.

In ordinary circumstances, sir, I would sooner be silent than challenge a request from the Chair, because I know when debate becomes heated we are all apt to forget ourselves a little. So far as I can remember, this is the first time I have ever spoken on a motion to adjourn the Senate. It is only because a keen sense of wrong and injustice is rankling in my mind that I have risen to make a protest against an act which I hope will never be repeated here. We all echoes words the other day when you referred to the manner in which the business of the Senate has been conducted during your tenure of office, which, of course, is coincident with the existence of the Senate. So far as honesty of purpose is concerned, hitherto there has never been a suspicion of unfairness or trickery having been practiced between one senator and another. Time and again I have given pairs to political opponents with whom I had no sympathy. When I first entered the Chamber I was unacquainted with parliamentary forms. I was unsophisticated so far as a knowledge of the tricks of the ”old parliamentary hand” was concerned. I readily gave a pair whenever I was asked, until, as a regular attendant. I began to realize that it could be carried to far. Pairing is a custom in the Chamber. Although it is not recognised by Standing Orders, yet it is strongly established customs. A pair-book is kept upon the table, pairs are recorded in Hansard, and a pair between two senators is looked upon as being as binding as their word of honour. When a pair is agreed to and afterwards broken we have a right to draw attention to the fact in the hope that the protest will have the effect of preventing a repetition of such conduct. God forbid that the Senate should ever again have experience of the kind it has had to-day! We do not wish our politics to be corrupted by such tactics.
What about the pairing a fortnight ago?
Senator Neild made a statement, Senator Pulsford made a statement, and we believed the latter.

Perhaps I had better refer to that pair, as it was referred to by Senator Millen this evening, and by Senator Neild a few days ago. It is all narrowed down to a question of the word of Senator Pulsford as against the word of Senator Neild.
Nothing of the kind. There is the pair-book to refer to.
In that case every senator voted as he wished to vote, but in this case he did not.
here is nothing dishonest in the fact that the name of Senator Gray had been substituted for the name of Senator Pulsford, the vote of every honorable senator being recorded in one way or other.
And with the consent of one of the parties to the pair.
What was the use of that when the consent of the other party was not asked?
It is a case of the word of one man against the word of another.
It is not a question of the word of either, because the pair is recorded in the pair-book.
Those who know Senator Pulsford will take his word just as readily as they will take Senator Neild's.
It is not a question of any one's word; and do not be so offensive.
Order!

I am not offensive when I compare Senator Pulsford with the honorable senator. Did he think that by changing his seat his size would scare me? Nothing of the kind. This is not the proper place for a scene.
I can sit where I like.
If the honorable senator meant business, this is not the place in which to make an exhibition.
Order! I must appeal to honorable senators to sustain the dignity of the Senate.
I shall look after the honorable senator.

All I have to say in regard to the sudden movement of Senator Neild from one end of the bench to the other is that there is a time and a place for an exhibition of that kind. I had nothing to do with the pair between Senator Neild and Senator Pulsford. When we remember that the pairs were all duly accounted for, and that every vote was carefully recorded-- --
Order!
No doubt it is amusing that what was intended to be a tragedy has turned out to be a farce. Perhaps it is just as well that it was a burlesque.
No doubt.

Had the division been sprung upon us this afternoon by any smart but honest action on the part of our opponents I would have been 'willing to give credit to them for their tactics The votes of honorable senators, recorded either in division lists or in the pair-book, show that there is a majority in favour of the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill, so that no one can say that it has been 'fairly defeated. Although the third reading has, on this occasion, been negatived, a majority of the Senate.is in favour of the Bill. I would a thousand times rather lose than secure victory by tactics such as have been adopted this afternoon. The opponents of the measure have won, but at a terrible cost to themselves, and I hope that what we have seen this afternoon will never be repeated in the history of this Chamber. Since the adjournment for dinner a telegram has been received from Senator Trenwith in regard to his pair. It has been implied by Senator Clemons, though no clear statement was made to which any one could reply directly, That Senator Trenwith was paired with Senator Symon. That, no doubt, is the inference drawn by nine-teiiths of those present.
There is no doubt about it. Senator Clemons said that Senator Symon and Senator Trenwith were paired.

We challenged Senator Fraser's vote, because we knew that he was paired with Senator Symon, and we were then given to understand that the pair had been changed. Has it been changed? I say that it has not, because Senator Trenwith states in his telegram—

quote.para: I had not paired with Senator Symon.

talk.start.para: So discraceful as that!
The man who should have known about the pair is ignorant of it.
Can a whip pair an honorable senator without his authority?
The pair is not in the pair-book.

As a matter off act, Senators Symon and Trenwith have not been paired. Speaking on Wednesday last, I said that I did not care whether the vote was taken that night, next day, or next week, so long as it was not a snatch vote, but gave the true expression of the opinion of the Senate. The reluctance to allow pairs in regard to the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill has been such as I have not known in regard to any other measure, and excited the suspicion in my mind that some trickery was afoot. I was a true seer, because the result has proved that the tactics which I apprehended were being pursued by our opponents. But without wishing to speak ungraciously, I feel that those who have been defeated are in a much more creditable position than that occupied by those who have won by such tactics.

As my name has been dragged into this discussion unnecessarily, I think it only fair to say a word or two. In the first place, I have no knowledge as to what has been going on in connexion with the arrangement of pairs upon the Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill.
Hear, hear. Every one thinks that.

I fought the Bill in this Chamber, but I have not fought it anywhere else. As to the observations with reference to the existence of the pair which I regard as having been broken, I being the victim of the breach, it is altogether too bad that it has been stated to be a question of credibility between Senator Pulsford and myself. It is not a question of credibility. I should not have mentioned the matter again, because it is most unpleasant for a senator who desires to be on terms of the closest friendship, not only with his colleagues from the State which he represents, but also with every other senator -
The honorable senator did not look very friendly a few moments ago
Because I was very much annoyed by an assertion which I am now refuting, the honorable senator having said that he preferred to take Senator Pulsford's word to mine.
I did not say anything of the kind.

Then I regret that I misrepresented the honorable senator. Someone said it, and the statement annoyed me. It is not a question of preferring any one's word, because the pair is entered in the pair-book in the following fashion: —

quote.para: DATE - August 17.
SUBJECT - Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta Railway Survey Bill.
PERIOD - Second Reading,
FOR - Senator Pulsford
AGAINST - 1no. C. Nield.

continue.para: Having written in those words, I submitted the entry to Senator Pulsford, so that he might agree to it, and then went away. My position in regard to the Bill is pretty well known. I was riot prepared to vote for the second reading until certain doubts in my mind, not in regard to engineering questions, but on questions of public policy, had been cleared up. Senators Croft and Pearce approached me a session or two ago, after I had announced my Opposition to the Bill, saying that I should vote against the second reading, and asked me f I would Vote for it on condition that the measure was referred to a Select Committee to investigate the difficulties which were perplexing me. I said that I would do that, and therefore voted for the second reading, but the second reading was not - carried even with my vote, I subsequently gave notice of motion for the appointment of a Select Committee to investigate the matter, but, owing to illness, I was prevented from proceeding with it. Can it therefore be said that my attitude was one of irreconcilability or persistent animosity to the measure? A month or two ago I was asked by the political party with which I am more or less connected to undertake certain work on its behalf, and my reply was that I could not get away unless I had a live pair On: the Bill. I then went to Senator Playford, and said, "If you go on with the Bill while I am away, you will lose two votes, because I have paired with Senator Pulsford; but if we are both here, and I can have a 'fair go for a Select Committee, I will vote for the second reading. Senator Puisford agreed to the pair without limitation of time, it being a pair for the "second reading, c." I went away in good faith. Something has been said about it being understood that I was going for three weeks. The statement is in Hansard. Is there anything about three weeks in the pair-book? If honorable senators will turn to the pair in the book between Senator Neild and Senator Gray they will find that it was made not at the end of three weeks, but at the end of two weeks. Now, whose word is entitled to be believed? I never said anything about three weeks. It was Senator Pulsford who said that, and it was he who transferred me from what I thought was a live pair to a pair with an honorable senator who was too ill to leave his bed.

talk.start.para: The honorable senator will admit that in the case he refers to, every honorable senator, voted as he wished, but in this case every honorable senator has not voted as he wished.

With that I have nothing whatever to do. I am speaking under a sense of regret that I have to make any further reference to a matter that involves the pleasant relations which have existed between myself and one of my colleagues in the representation of New South Wales, or between myself and another member of the Senate. But to-night I was plainly told by some honorable senator that it was a question of creditability as between Senator Pulsford and myself, and some honorable senator interjected that he would prefer to believe Senator Pulsford. I say the pair-book absolutely proves beyond the possibility of doubt that the pair I had made in all good faith was transferred to a pair with an honorable senator whose vote was in operative, and it was only by that process of transfer that the second reading of the Bill was carried.
Was not the honorable senator's vote inoperative also?

The sound of Senator McGregor's voice recalls to my memory a. tact which I have publicly acknowledged in my own State, and which I am very pleased to be able to acknowledge here, that when I was on a supposed death-bed last year, and was absent by leave of the Senate, the party to which Senator McGregor belongs, and the honorable senator himself, paid me the high personal compliment, and my State the high and distinguished piece of fair dealing of giving me a pair all the time of my illness, when I was utterly unable to be here. I am very glad that I have this opportunity of acknowledging that pair in as public a manner in this Chamber as I have done under my hand in the newspapers of the capital city of my State, and as I have done in addressing public audiences in that State.
That was only fair, and it recognised the rights of the State.

It was more than fair. It was handsome treatment, because I was on leave, and I do not think I was entitled to a pair. I am proud to have been the subject of so much goodwill, and I thank the members of the Senate throughout for any courtesy of that kind they extended to me at the time. I wish to say that as to the pair which has been discussed this afternoon, I know no more about it than does the waste-paper basket. I have not been in the confidence of those who have been conducting a hard-fought campaign, but I have heard sufficient to make me believe that there has been misapprehension. It is pretty well known to honorable senators that Senator Clemons and I have not always been the best of friends in times past, and are not on special terms of friendship now; but I have heard enough to convince me that whatever mistake has been made it will be found, when the whole truth has been told, that Senator Clemons is not entitled to the blame attributed to him.
Would not that wire indicate that he was?

I am not prepared to discuss the wire, because I do not know exactly how it is worded. It appears to me that Senator Trenwith was paired by both sides, but I do not know the full significance of the pair, and really know so little of the matter that I am not qualified at the present stage to pass any opinion upon it. But from something which has reached my ears, I think it will be found that Senator Clemons is not entitled to receive the strictures passed upon him. I say that on behalf of an absent man, and a man whom no one will allege to have been my personal friend since I met him here. There have been hot passages between us more often than friendly ones, but I like a fair deal all round, and I would not say an i ugly word against the devil himself merely because he was the devil, or because we might meet some day at closer quarters than would be pleasant. I hope that what I have said will tend to disabuse the minds of honorable senators of any feeling of ill-will, and to check this process of washing dirty linen, which is not to the credit of the Senate. It will do us no good. If there is something definite to be said there might not be so much harm, but I hope the good sense of honorable senators will induce them to refrain from statements based on imputations and suspicions. They are naturally suffering from a sense of annoyance. When in Brisbane, last week, I read of a certain pair, I suffered from a sense of annoyance, and I came here feeling very' much annoyed. However, I do not think that I took up much time in making a grievance of it, and certainly not so much time as I have had to occupy tonight in trying to put things straight. I beg honorable senators opposite to accept my assurance that if there is a grievance on one side, there has also been a grievance on the other. What has happened will necessarily be definitely cleared up before the end of the session, better than we can hope it will be cleared up tonight by accusations which have not a sufficient degree of proof in support of them to warrant our continuing a discussion which, however much it might relieve the annoyance of individuals, does not tend to sustain the orderly reputation of the Senate, or to promote the personal good-will which I most sincerely hope may exist amongst honorable senators, particularly at a time when half the members of the Senate are approaching the end of the period of their service, and will have to seek a renewal of public confidence before they will again meet those of us who are more happily placed.

I am very pleased to hear that Senator Neild repudiates any knowledge of anything of a character which might be repugnant to the taste of honorable senators, present or absent. I am not going to blame anyone. I hope that before the end of the session is reached, the difficulty will be cleared up, and that good feeling will again prevail amongst the honorable senators before they part. But I wish to make a statement which has some bearing on what really transpired, because I think it is due not only to honorable senators, but to the public, in the interests of the confidence which should be reposed in the Senate, that such a statement should be made. On Wednesday last, late in the afternoon, I approached Senator Fraser, having been led to believe that he was anxious to get away, and it was convenient also for myself to go away. I asked the honorable senator for a pair, and we arranged that pair. I considered that it continued. Yesterday morning, Senator Guthrie desired to get away, and I was present. I am making this statement to show the difference in the methods adopted in connexion with pars Senator Guthrie came to me and said: "Are you willing to transfer your pair with Senator Fraser to me?" and I replied, "I cannot do that without Senator Fraser's Consent." Senator Fraser just then came into the Chamber, and I said to Senator Guthrie, "If you can get Senator Fraser's consent, I am willing to transfer the pair." Senator Fraser's consent was obtained, and that was a legitimate transaction. Senator Guthrie informed me that he was paired with Senator Fraser until 1 o'clock yesterday, at which hour Senator Fraser became paired with Senator Symon. That is exactly what occurred. If, an hour or less before the division was taken, Senator Fraser told Senator Findley, in the presence of Senator Croft, that he was paired- -well, there is some explanation necessary, and I hope that one will be made. I should not like to accuse a gentleman of the age of Senator Fraser, and of his standing in Victoria and in this Senate, of saying what was not true, or of in any way misleading any other honorable senator; but there is some explanation required. When Senator Clemons says that Senator Symon was in favour of the Bill and that Senator Trenwith was against it, and then makes no further statement—when we now have a wire from Senator Trenwith saying that he was not paired with Senator Symon—further explanation is necessary before that harmony and good feeling which has existed hitherto can be restored.

I re-echo the sincere hope of Senators Neild and McGregor that such explanations will be forthcoming as to render the position at least different from what it at present appears to be. I trust that during the present session we shall be able to wipe out the stain that apparently rests on some of the transactions of this day. I have the strongest feelings of disapprobation for any conduct that is at all of a shady character. It is possible to fight even a lion when it is roaring in your path, tut if even a small, insignificant man is secretly engineering in order to deceive or defeat you, it is a hard task to defend yourself. From the evidence placed before the Senate by Senator de Largie, it appears that, either wilfully or otherwise, efforts, that cannot be regarded as reputable, have been made to defeat a certain proposal before the Senate. When Senator Clemons made an attempt to show that his honour was unsullied—that his hands were absolutely clean, and that it was impossible for any one to hurl accusations of dishonorable practice against him—he said, "Senator Trenwith was opposed to the Bill, and Senator Symon was in favour of the Bill, and that is all I have to say about it; I have done nothing other than what any honest man could possibly do under the circumstances." The telegram from Senator Trenwith, informing us that he was never paired with Senator Symon, shows clearly that if the pair with Senator Fraser was transferred, no other conclusion can be arrived at than that the man who transferred it has been guilty, of a gross breach of all political honour. What would we on this side have done under similar circumstances? Senator Matheson is strongly in favour of this Railway Survey Bill, and we might legitimately, and honesty have urged that fact. We might have gone on to say that Senator Best is opposed to the Bill, and to ask why we should not transfer the pair of Senator Drake, who is favourable to the Bill, from Senator Best, and place Senator Best and Senator Matheson as a pair, leaving Senator Drake to exercise honesty his vote in the Senate. What would have been said by honorable senators opposite if we had been guilty of such a transaction. Rather than attempt anything of that sort, we would be prepared to suffer any kind of defeat. I am glad that, although we have been defeated, we have been defeated with all our colours still floating in the sight of Australia.

I have to express very great regret, as a member of the Senate, at the occurrence this afternoon. When I was elected to the Senate, I had a great belief in the honour of members of this Parliament. I always looked upon any private arrangements in which the pair-book played a part as being in the nature of honorable compacts which no senator would think of breaking. On this occasion, however and, unfortunately, in the early part of the afternoon, I had a suspicion that something of the kind was being done--the compact has been broken. It was generally understood that Senator Fraser had been paired with Senator Symon.
It was publicly stated.

An arrangement was entered into by which pairs were to be provided for all honorable senators who could not be present to vote, and the Government asked to be assisted to get the measure through. This afternoon, when the bells rang for the division, Senator Fraser came in and recorded his vote. About an hour before, I was carrying on a conversation with him in one of the rooms outside the Chamber when Senator Finley came in, and, evidently with the idea of securing a pair for himself, asked Senator Fraser, "Are you paired?" Senator Fraser replied. "Oh, yes."
And when I said that there was to be an all-night sitting, he stated that he would not take' part in it.

Yes; he said that he was not going to injure his health by remaining here all night. I cannot believe that there has been an accident. One of two things has happened. Either Senator Fraser has deliberately broken his word—has told a lie by giving it forth that he was paired and did not intend to vote, or he has been over persuaded to give his vote by those who have been taking part in the organized opposition to this Bill. A number of honorable senators have repeatedly met and discussed the best tactics to pursue in opposing the measure.
At most, there were only one or two to blame.

I know that in most of these movements the leaders are responsible for what is done. Before we can regard the pair-book as reliable, and before some of the whips can approach others in order to make arrangements for pairs, we must have a proper explanation with regard to what happened this afternoon. When the principles of the Labour Party are at stake, the voting is generally very close, and we cannot enter into any arrangements in the future such as those which have been made in the past until this matter has been cleared up. I have allowed myself to say, outside this Chamber, that I felt it very, keenly that certain members of the Labour Party might be implicated in this matter. I do not think, however, that they had any knowledge of the tactics that were being adopted. If they had, they would be no longer worthy to be associated with the party to which I belong. I cannot believe that Senator Higgs or Senator Givens were parties to what took place.
I had nothing what ever to do with any pair but my own.
Senator Trenwith's telegram tends to show that nothing less than the paltriest kind of trickery was resorted to.
